arXiv:2410.04907v1 [math.CO] 07 Oct 2024

Decomposition Polyhedra of Piecewise
Linear Functions

Marie-Charlotte Brandenburg
KTH Royal Institute of Technology
brandenburg@kth.se
&Moritz Grillo
Technische Universit√§t Berlin
grillo@math.tu-berlin.de
&Christoph Hertrich
Universit√© libre de Bruxelles
christoph.hertrich@ulb.be
Abstract

In this paper we contribute to the frequently studied question of how to decompose a continuous piecewise linear (CPWL) function into a difference of two convex CPWL functions. Every CPWL function has infinitely many such decompositions, but for applications in optimization and neural network theory, it is crucial to find decompositions with as few linear pieces as possible. This is a highly challenging problem, as we further demonstrate by disproving a recently proposed approach by Tran & Wang (2024). To make the problem more tractable, we propose to fix an underlying polyhedral complex determining the possible locus of nonlinearity. Under this assumption, we prove that the set of decompositions forms a polyhedron that arises as intersection of two translated cones. We prove that irreducible decompositions correspond to the bounded faces of this polyhedron and minimal solutions must be vertices. We then identify cases with a unique minimal decomposition, and illustrate how our insights have consequences in the theory of submodular functions. Finally, we improve upon previous constructions of neural networks for a given convex CPWL function and apply our framework to obtain results in the nonconvex case.

1 Introduction

Continuous piecewise linear (CPWL) functions play a crucial role in optimization and machine learning. While they have traditionally been used to describe problems in geometry, discrete and submodular optimization, or statistical regression, they recently gained significant interest as functions represented by neural networks with rectified linear unit (ReLU) activations (Arora et al., 2018). Extensive research has been put into understanding which neural network architectures are capable of representing which CPWL functions (Chen et al., 2022; Haase et al., 2023; Hertrich et al., 2021). A major source of complexity in all the aforementioned fields is nonconvexity. Indeed, not only are nonconvex optimization problems generally much harder to solve than convex ones, but also for neural networks, nonconvexities are usually responsible for making the obtained representations complicated.

It is a well-known folklore fact that every (potentially nonconvex) CWPL function f:‚Ñùn‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëì‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëõ‚Ñùf\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R can be written as the difference f=g‚àíhùëìùëî‚Ñéf=g-hitalic_f = italic_g - italic_h of two convex CPWL functions (Melzer, 1986; Kripfganz & Schulze, 1987). Consequently, a natural idea to circumvent the challenges induced by nonconvexity is to use such a decomposition f=g‚àíhùëìùëî‚Ñéf=g-hitalic_f = italic_g - italic_h and solve the desired problem separately for gùëîgitalic_g and h‚Ñéhitalic_h. This is the underlying idea of many successful optimization routines, known as DC programming (see survey by Le Thi & Pham Dinh (2018)), and also occurs in the analysis of neural networks (Zhang et al., 2018). However, the crucial question arising from this strategy is: how much more complex are gùëîgitalic_g and h‚Ñéhitalic_h compared to fùëìfitalic_f? A well-established measure for the complexity of a CPWL function is the number of its linear pieces. Therefore, the main question we study in this article is the following.

Problem 1.1.

How to decompose a CPWL function fùëìfitalic_f into a difference f=g‚àíhùëìùëî‚Ñéf=g-hitalic_f = italic_g - italic_h of two convex CPWL functions with as few pieces as possible?

There exist many ways in the literature to obtain such a decomposition, as we discuss later, but none of them guarantees minimality or at least a useful bound on the number of pieces of gùëîgitalic_g and h‚Ñéhitalic_h depending on those of fùëìfitalic_f. In fact, no finite procedure is known that guarantees to find a minimal decomposition, despite a recent attempt by Tran & Wang (2024).

1.1 Our Contributions

In this article, we propose a novel perspective on 1.1 making use of polyhedral geometry and prove a number of structural results. We then apply our approach to existing decompositions in the literature, as well as to the theory of submodular functions and to the construction of neural networks representing a given CPWL function, serving as an additional motivation. Our detailed contributions are outlined as follows.

Decomposition Polyhedra.

After setting the preliminaries in Section 2, Section 3 presents our new polyhedral approach to 1.1. Instead of aiming for a globally optimal decomposition, we propose to restrict to solutions that are compatible with a given regular polyhedral complex ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P. In short, this means fixing where the functions gùëîgitalic_g and h‚Ñéhitalic_h may have breakpoints, that is, points where they are not locally linear. We prove that the set of solutions to decompose fùëìfitalic_f in a way that is compatible with ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P is a polyhedron ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí´ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) that arises as the intersection of two shifted polyhedral cones. We call this the decomposition polyhedron of fùëìfitalic_f with respect to ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P. We prove several structural properties of ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí´ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ). Among them, we show that the bounded faces of ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí´ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) are exactly those that cannot easily be simplified by subtracting a convex function, and we show that a minimal solution must be a vertex of ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí´ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ). The latter implies a finite procedure to find a minimal decomposition among those that are compatible with ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P, by simply enumerating the vertices of ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí´ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ). It also implies that, if only a single vertex exists, then there is a unique minimal decomposition. We demonstrate that this is indeed the case for important CPWL functions, e.g., the median function, or those computed by a 1-hidden-layer ReLU network.

Existing Decompositions.

Afterwards, in Section 4, we put our investigations into a broader context within the existing literature. We compare our minimality conditions with existing methods to construct decompositions. Notably, in this context, we refute a conjecture by Tran & Wang (2024), who provide an optimal construction method in dimension 2 and suggest that it might generalize to higher dimensions. We show that it does not.

Applications to Submodular Function.

In Section 5, we show that our framework entails the setup of set functions which are decomposed into differences of submodular set functions. Representing a set function as such a difference is a popular approach to solve optimization problems similarly to DC programming, see Narasimhan & Bilmes (2005); Iyer & Bilmes (2012); El Halabi et al. (2023). We apply our results from Section 3 to obtain analogous structural insights about (submodular) set functions.

Application to Neural Network Constructions.

Finally, in Section 6, we study the problem of constructing neural networks representing a given CPWL function. For convex CPWL functions, we blend two incomparable previous constructions by Hertrich et al. (2021) and Chen et al. (2022) to let the user freely choose a trade-off between depth and width of the constructed networks. We then apply the results of this paper to extend this to the nonconvex case by first decomposing the input function as a difference of two convex ones.

Limitations.

We emphasize that the focus of our paper is fundamental research by building a theoretical foundation to tackle 1.1 and connecting it with other fields. As such, our paper does not imply any direct improvement for a practical task, but it might prove helpful for that in the future. In particular, it is beyond the scope of our paper to provide any implementation of a (heuristic or exact) method to decompose a CPWL function into a difference of two convex ones. We consider it an exciting avenue for future research to do so, and to apply it to DC programming, discrete optimization, or neural networks.

On the theoretical side, the approach of fixing an underlying compatible polyhedral complex imposes some restriction on the set of possible solutions and can therefore be seen as a limitation. However, we think that this assumption is well justified by the structural properties this assumption allows us to infer and by the examples we demonstrate to fit into the framework. Even with this assumption, the problem remains very challenging.

1.2 Further Related Work

Explicit constructions to decompose CPWL functions as differences of convex CPWL functions can be found in several articles, such as Kripfganz & Schulze (1987); Zalgaller (2000); Wang (2004); Schl√ºter & Darup (2021). This was initiated in the 1111-dimensional case by Bittner (1970), and already laid out for positively homogeneous functions in general dimensions by Melzer (1986). Typically, such decompositions are based on certain representations of CPWL functions, which have been constructed, e.g., in Tarela & Martinez (1999); Ovchinnikov (2002); Wang & Sun (2005); see also Koutschan et al. (2023; 2024) for a fresh perspective. These representations also help to understand the representative capabilities of neural networks, see Arora et al. (2018); Hertrich et al. (2021); Chen et al. (2022).

Recently, a minimal decomposition for the 2222-dimensional case was given by Tran & Wang (2024). They use a duality between CPWL functions and polyhedral geometry, based on the ‚Äúbalancing condition‚Äù from tropical geometry. This condition has already been studied by McMullen (1996) in terms of weight spaces of polytopes. Generally, methods from tropical geometry have been successfully used to understand the geometry of neural networks, see e.g. Zhang et al. (2018); Hertrich et al. (2021); Mont√∫far et al. (2022); Haase et al. (2023); Brandenburg et al. (2024).

Submodular functions are sometimes called the discrete analogue of convex functions, and optimizing over them is a widely studied problem, which is also relevant for machine learning. A submodular function can be minimized in polynomial time (Gr√∂tschel et al., 1981). In analogy to DC programming, this sparked the idea of minimizing a general set function by representing it as a difference of two submodular ones (Narasimhan & Bilmes, 2005; Iyer & Bilmes, 2012; El Halabi et al., 2023). Related decompositions were recently studied by B√©rczi et al. (2024). In polyhderal theory, such a decomposition is equivalent to Minkowski differences of generalized permutahedra (Ardila et al., 2009; Jochemko & Ravichandran, 2022).

Another closely related stream of work is concerned with the (exact and approximate) representative capabilities of neural networks, starting with universal approximation theorems (Cybenko, 1989), and specializing to ReLU networks, their number of pieces, as well as depth-width-tradeoffs (Telgarsky, 2016; Eldan & Shamir, 2016; Arora et al., 2018). In addition, Hertrich & Skutella (2023); Hertrich & Sering (2024) provide neural network constructions for CPWL functions related to combinatorial optimization problems. Geometric insights have also proven to be useful to understand the computational complexity of training neural networks (Froese et al., 2022; Bertschinger et al., 2024; Froese & Hertrich, 2024). Recently, Safran et al. (2024) give an explicit construction of how to efficiently approximate the maximum function with ReLU networks.

2 Preliminaries

In this section we introduce the necessary preliminaries on polyhedral geometry and CPWL functions. For m‚àà‚Ñïùëö‚Ñïm\in\mathbb{N}italic_m ‚àà blackboard_N, we write [m]‚âî{1,2,‚Ä¶,m}‚âîdelimited-[]ùëö12‚Ä¶ùëö[m]\coloneqq\{1,2,\dots,m\}[ italic_m ] ‚âî { 1 , 2 , ‚Ä¶ , italic_m }.

Polyhedra and Polyhedral Complexes.

A polyhedron PùëÉPitalic_P is the intersection of finitely many closed halfspaces and a polytope is a bounded polyhedron. A hyperplane supports PùëÉPitalic_P if it bounds a closed halfspace containing PùëÉPitalic_P, and any intersection of PùëÉPitalic_P with such a supporting hyperplane yields a face FùêπFitalic_F of PùëÉPitalic_P. A face is a proper face if F‚ääPùêπùëÉF\subsetneq Pitalic_F ‚ää italic_P and inclusion-maximal proper faces are referred to as facets. A polyhedral cone C‚äÜ‚Ñùnùê∂superscript‚ÑùùëõC\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_C ‚äÜ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a polyhedron such that Œª‚Å¢u+Œº‚Å¢v‚ààCùúÜùë¢ùúáùë£ùê∂\lambda u+\mu v\in Citalic_Œª italic_u + italic_Œº italic_v ‚àà italic_C for every u,v‚ààCùë¢ùë£ùê∂u,v\in Citalic_u , italic_v ‚àà italic_C and Œª,Œº‚àà‚Ñù‚â•0ùúÜùúásubscript‚Ñùabsent0\lambda,\mu\in\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}italic_Œª , italic_Œº ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â• 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The dual cone of Cùê∂Citalic_C is C‚à®={y‚àà(‚Ñùn)‚àó‚à£‚ü®x,y‚ü©‚â•0‚Å¢ for all ‚Å¢x‚ààC}.superscriptùê∂conditional-setùë¶superscriptsuperscript‚Ñùùëõùë•ùë¶0 for all ùë•ùê∂C^{\vee}=\{y\in(\mathbb{R}^{n})^{*}\mid\langle x,y\rangle\geq 0\text{ for all % }x\in C\}.italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à® end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { italic_y ‚àà ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à£ ‚ü® italic_x , italic_y ‚ü© ‚â• 0 for all italic_x ‚àà italic_C } . A cone is pointed if it does not contain a line. A cone Cùê∂Citalic_C is simplicial, if there are linearly independent vectors v1,‚Ä¶,vk‚àà‚Ñùnsubscriptùë£1‚Ä¶subscriptùë£ùëòsuperscript‚Ñùùëõv_{1},\ldots,v_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that C={‚àëi=1kŒªi‚Å¢vi‚à£Œªi‚â•0}ùê∂conditional-setsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëòsubscriptùúÜùëñsubscriptùë£ùëñsubscriptùúÜùëñ0C=\{\sum_{i=1}^{k}\lambda_{i}v_{i}\mid\lambda_{i}\geq 0\}italic_C = { ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à£ italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â• 0 }. For a cone Cùê∂Citalic_C and t‚àà‚Ñùnùë°superscript‚Ñùùëõt\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_t ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we call t+Cùë°ùê∂t+Citalic_t + italic_C a shifted cone or translated cone.

A polyhedral complex ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P is a finite collection of polyhedra such that (i) ‚àÖ‚ààùí´ùí´\emptyset\in\mathcal{P}‚àÖ ‚àà caligraphic_P, (ii) if P‚ààùí´ùëÉùí´P\in\mathcal{P}italic_P ‚àà caligraphic_P then all faces of PùëÉPitalic_P are in ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P, and (iii) if P,P‚Ä≤‚ààùí´ùëÉsuperscriptùëÉ‚Ä≤ùí´P,P^{\prime}\in\mathcal{P}italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà caligraphic_P, then P‚à©P‚Ä≤ùëÉsuperscriptùëÉ‚Ä≤P\cap P^{\prime}italic_P ‚à© italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a face both of PùëÉPitalic_P and P‚Ä≤superscriptùëÉ‚Ä≤P^{\prime}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For a polyhedral complex ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P in ‚Ñùnsuperscript‚Ñùùëõ\mathbb{R}^{n}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we denote by ùí´dsuperscriptùí´ùëë\mathcal{P}^{d}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the set of dùëëditalic_d-dimensional polyhedra in ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P. Given two nùëõnitalic_n-dimensional polyhedral complexes ùí´,ùí¨ùí´ùí¨\mathcal{P},\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_Q, the complex ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P is a refinement of ùí¨ùí¨\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q if for every œÑ‚ààùí´nùúèsuperscriptùí´ùëõ\tau\in\mathcal{P}^{n}italic_œÑ ‚àà caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT there exists œÉ‚ààùí¨nùúésuperscriptùí¨ùëõ\sigma\in\mathcal{Q}^{n}italic_œÉ ‚àà caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that œÑ‚äÜœÉùúèùúé\tau\subseteq\sigmaitalic_œÑ ‚äÜ italic_œÉ. The complex ùí¨ùí¨\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q is a coarsening of ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P if ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P is a refinement of ùí¨ùí¨\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q.

The star of a face œÑ‚ààùí´ùúèùí´\tau\in\mathcal{P}italic_œÑ ‚àà caligraphic_P is the set of all faces containing œÑùúè\tauitalic_œÑ, i.e., starùí´‚Å°(œÑ)={œÉ‚ààùí´‚à£œÑ‚äÜœÉ}subscriptstarùí´ùúèconditional-setùúéùí´ùúèùúé\operatorname{star}_{\mathcal{P}}(\tau)=\{\sigma\in\mathcal{P}\mid\tau% \subseteq\sigma\}roman_star start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œÑ ) = { italic_œÉ ‚àà caligraphic_P ‚à£ italic_œÑ ‚äÜ italic_œÉ }. We only consider complete polyhedral complexes, that is, complexes which cover ‚Ñùnsuperscript‚Ñùùëõ\mathbb{R}^{n}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. A polyhedral fan is a polyhedral complex in which every polyhedron is a cone.

An nùëõnitalic_n-dimensional polyhedral complex can be equipped with a weight function w:ùí´n‚àí1‚Üí‚Ñù:ùë§‚Üísuperscriptùí´ùëõ1‚Ñùw:\mathcal{P}^{n-1}\to\mathbb{R}italic_w : caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R, as we describe as follows. Given a face œÉ‚ààùí´ùúéùí´\sigma\in\mathcal{P}italic_œÉ ‚àà caligraphic_P, we denote by aff‚Å°(œÉ)‚äÜ‚Ñùnaffùúésuperscript‚Ñùùëõ\operatorname{aff}(\sigma)\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{n}roman_aff ( italic_œÉ ) ‚äÜ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the unique smallest affine subspace containing œÉùúé\sigmaitalic_œÉ. The relative interior of œÉùúé\sigmaitalic_œÉ is the interior of œÉùúé\sigmaitalic_œÉ inside the affine space aff‚Å°(œÉ)affùúé\operatorname{aff}(\sigma)roman_aff ( italic_œÉ ). For any dimension d‚â§nùëëùëõd\leq nitalic_d ‚â§ italic_n and any œÑ‚ààùí´d‚àí1,œÉ‚ààùí´dformulae-sequenceùúèsuperscriptùí´ùëë1ùúésuperscriptùí´ùëë\tau\in\mathcal{P}^{d-1},\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{d}italic_œÑ ‚àà caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_œÉ ‚àà caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with œÑ‚äÜœÉùúèùúé\tau\subseteq\sigmaitalic_œÑ ‚äÜ italic_œÉ, let eœÉ/œÑ‚àà‚Ñùnsubscriptùëíùúéùúèsuperscript‚Ñùùëõe_{\sigma/\tau}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÉ / italic_œÑ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the normal vector of œÑùúè\tauitalic_œÑ with respect to œÉùúé\sigmaitalic_œÉ, that is, the unique vector with length one that is parallel to aff‚Å°(œÉ)affùúé\operatorname{aff}(\sigma)roman_aff ( italic_œÉ ), orthogonal to aff‚Å°(œÑ)affùúè\operatorname{aff}(\tau)roman_aff ( italic_œÑ ), and points from the relative interior of œÑùúè\tauitalic_œÑ into the relative interior of œÉùúé\sigmaitalic_œÉ. A pair (ùí´,w)ùí´ùë§(\mathcal{P},w)( caligraphic_P , italic_w ) forms a balanced (weighted) polyhedral complex if the weight function satisfies the balancing condition at every œÑ‚ààùí´n‚àí2ùúèsuperscriptùí´ùëõ2\tau\in\mathcal{P}^{n-2}italic_œÑ ‚àà caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT:

‚àëœÉ‚ààùí´n‚àí1:œÉ‚äÉœÑw‚Å¢(œÉ)‚ãÖeœÉ/œÑ=0subscript:ùúésuperscriptùí´ùëõ1absentùúèùúé‚ãÖùë§ùúésubscriptùëíùúéùúè0\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}:\\ \sigma\supset\tau\end{subarray}}w(\sigma)\cdot e_{\sigma/\tau}=0‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_œÉ ‚àà caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_œÉ ‚äÉ italic_œÑ end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w ( italic_œÉ ) ‚ãÖ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÉ / italic_œÑ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0

Continuous Piecewise Linear Functions.

A function f:‚Ñùn‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëì‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëõ‚Ñùf\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R is called continuous and piecewise linear (CPWL), if there exists a polyhedral complex ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P such that the restriction of fùëìfitalic_f to each full-dimensional polyhedron P‚ààùí´nùëÉsuperscriptùí´ùëõP\in\mathcal{P}^{n}italic_P ‚àà caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an affine function. If this condition is satisfied, we say that fùëìfitalic_f and ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P are compatible with each other.

In line with Chen et al. (2022), we define the number of pieces qùëûqitalic_q of fùëìfitalic_f to be the smallest possible number |ùí´n|superscriptùí´ùëõ\lvert\mathcal{P}^{n}\rvert| caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | of full-dimensional regions of a compatible polyhedral complex ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P. Note that this requires pieces to be convex sets, as they are polyhedra. The function fùëìfitalic_f might realize the same affine function on distinct pieces P,Q‚ààùí´nùëÉùëÑsuperscriptùí´ùëõP,Q\in\mathcal{P}^{n}italic_P , italic_Q ‚àà caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. To account for that, we define the number of affine components kùëòkitalic_k to be the the number of different affine functions realized on all the pieces in ùí´nsuperscriptùí´ùëõ\mathcal{P}^{n}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Note that this quantity is independent of the choice of the particular compatible complex ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P.

It holds that k‚â§q‚â§k!ùëòùëûùëòk\leq q\leq k!italic_k ‚â§ italic_q ‚â§ italic_k ! and each of these inequalities can be strict, compare the discussion by Chen et al. (2022). We can assume that k>nùëòùëõk>nitalic_k > italic_n (and thus q>nùëûùëõq>nitalic_q > italic_n) because otherwise fùëìfitalic_f can be written as a composition of an affine projection to a lower dimension n‚Ä≤superscriptùëõ‚Ä≤n^{\prime}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT followed by a CPWL function defined on ‚Ñùn‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñùsuperscriptùëõ‚Ä≤\mathbb{R}^{n^{\prime}}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

If fùëìfitalic_f is a convex CPWL function, then it can be written as the maximum of finitely many affine functions f‚Å¢(x)=maxi‚àà[k]‚Å°gi‚Å¢(x)ùëìùë•subscriptùëñdelimited-[]ùëòsubscriptùëîùëñùë•f(x)=\max_{i\in[k]}g_{i}(x)italic_f ( italic_x ) = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ italic_k ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ). It follows that there is a unique coarsest compatible polyhedral complex ùí´fsubscriptùí´ùëì\mathcal{P}_{f}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, namely the one with ùí´fn={{x‚à£gi‚Å¢(x)=maxj‚Å°gj‚Å¢(x)}‚à£i‚àà[k]}superscriptsubscriptùí´ùëìùëõconditional-setconditional-setùë•subscriptùëîùëñùë•subscriptùëósubscriptùëîùëóùë•ùëñdelimited-[]ùëò\mathcal{P}_{f}^{n}=\{\{x\mid g_{i}(x)=\max_{j}g_{j}(x)\}\mid i\in[k]\}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { { italic_x ‚à£ italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) } ‚à£ italic_i ‚àà [ italic_k ] }. In particular, we have k=qùëòùëûk=qitalic_k = italic_q if fùëìfitalic_f is convex. We call a polyhedral complex ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P regular, if there exists a convex CPWL function fùëìfitalic_f such that ùí´=ùí´fùí´subscriptùí´ùëì\mathcal{P}=\mathcal{P}_{f}caligraphic_P = caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

3 Decomposition Polyhedra

In this section, we introduce and generally study the main concept of the paper, decomposition polyhedra. These polyhedra describe the set of possible decompositions of a CPWL function fùëìfitalic_f into a difference f=g‚àíhùëìùëî‚Ñéf=g-hitalic_f = italic_g - italic_h that are compatible with a given polyhedral complex. We start by establishing a handful of general results concerning the space of CPWL functions compatible with a given polyhedral complex. Proofs that are omitted from the main text as well as some auxiliary statements can be found in Appendix E.

Lemma 3.1.

Let ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P be a polyhredral complex. The set of CPWL functions compatible with ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P forms a linear subspace ùí±ùí´subscriptùí±ùí´\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the space of continuous functions.

Let Aff‚Å°(‚Ñùn)Affsuperscript‚Ñùùëõ\operatorname{Aff}(\mathbb{R}^{n})roman_Aff ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) be the space of affine functions from ‚Ñùnsuperscript‚Ñùùëõ\mathbb{R}^{n}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R}blackboard_R. For many of our arguments, adding or subtracting an affine function a‚ààAff‚Å°(‚Ñùn)ùëéAffsuperscript‚Ñùùëõa\in\operatorname{Aff}(\mathbb{R}^{n})italic_a ‚àà roman_Aff ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) does not change anything. In particular, a function fùëìfitalic_f is convex if and only if f+aùëìùëéf+aitalic_f + italic_a is convex. Therefore it makes sense to define the quotient space ùí±¬Øùí´‚âîùí±ùí´/Aff‚Å°(‚Ñùn)‚âîsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´subscriptùí±ùí´Affsuperscript‚Ñùùëõ\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}\coloneqq\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}/% \operatorname{Aff}(\mathbb{R}^{n})over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚âî caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / roman_Aff ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), where we identify functions in ùí±ùí´subscriptùí±ùí´\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that only differ by adding an affine function. The following lemma shows that we can parameterize a function f‚ààùí±¬Øùí´ùëìsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´f\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_f ‚àà over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by keeping track of ‚Äúhow convex or concave‚Äù the function is at the common face œÉ‚ààùí´n‚àí1ùúésuperscriptùí´ùëõ1\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}italic_œÉ ‚àà caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of two neighboring pieces. For the case that wùë§witalic_w is nonnegative and rational, the lemma follows from the structure theorem of tropical geometry (Maclagan & Sturmfels, 2015). In Section E.2, we present a generalization of the proof adapted to our setting.

Lemma 3.2.

The vector space ùí≤ùí´‚âî{w:ùí´n‚àí1‚Üí‚Ñù‚à£(ùí´,w)\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}\coloneqq\{w\colon\mathcal{P}^{n-1}\to\mathbb{R}\mid(% \mathcal{P},w)caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚âî { italic_w : caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R ‚à£ ( caligraphic_P , italic_w ) is balanced}}\}} is isomorphic to ùí±¬Øùí´subscript¬Øùí±ùí´\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Figure 1 illustrates the different parameterizations of the median function according to Lemma 3.2. Moreover, from Lemma 3.2 we can deduce that ùí±ùí´subscriptùí±ùí´\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is finite-dimensional (Corollary E.1) and the following proposition.

Proposition 3.3.

A function f‚ààùí±ùí´ùëìsubscriptùí±ùí´f\in\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_f ‚àà caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is convex if and only if wfsubscriptùë§ùëìw_{f}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is nonnegative. Moreover, fùëìfitalic_f is convex with ùí´=ùí´fùí´subscriptùí´ùëì\mathcal{P}=\mathcal{P}_{f}caligraphic_P = caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT if and only if wfsubscriptùë§ùëìw_{f}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is strictly positive.

The set ùí±¬Øùí´+superscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of convex functions in ùí±¬Øùí´subscript¬Øùí±ùí´\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT forms a polyhedral cone (Lemma E.2). In the following, we now fix a function f‚ààùí±ùí´ùëìsubscriptùí±ùí´f\in\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_f ‚àà caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and consider the space of decompositions f=g‚àíhùëìùëî‚Ñéf=g-hitalic_f = italic_g - italic_h into differences of convex functions which are also compatible with ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P. In Lemma E.3, we show that for a regular complex ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P such a decomposition does indeed always exist. In particular, ùí±¬Øùí´=span‚Å°(ùí±¬Øùí´+)subscript¬Øùí±ùí´spansuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}=\operatorname{span}(\overline{\mathcal{V}% }_{\mathcal{P}}^{+})over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_span ( over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), which implies that dim(ùí±¬Øùí´)=dim(ùí±¬Øùí´+)dimensionsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´dimensionsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´\dim(\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}})=\dim(\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{% \mathcal{P}}^{+})roman_dim ( over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = roman_dim ( over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

Definition 3.4.

For a CPWL function fùëìfitalic_f and a polyhedral complex ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P, the decomposition polyhedron of fùëìfitalic_f with respect to ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P is ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)‚âî{(g,h)‚à£g,h‚ààùí±¬Øùí´+,f=g‚àíh}.‚âîsubscriptùíüùí´ùëìconditional-setùëî‚Ñéformulae-sequenceùëî‚Ñésuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´ùëìùëî‚Ñé\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)\coloneqq\{(g,h)\mid g,h\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_% {\mathcal{P}}^{+},f=g-h\}.caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ‚âî { ( italic_g , italic_h ) ‚à£ italic_g , italic_h ‚àà over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_f = italic_g - italic_h } .

The projection œÄ‚Å¢((g,h))=gùúãùëî‚Ñéùëî\pi((g,h))=gitalic_œÄ ( ( italic_g , italic_h ) ) = italic_g induces an isomorphism between ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí´ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) and œÄ‚Å¢(ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f))ùúãsubscriptùíüùí´ùëì\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))italic_œÄ ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ) since ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)={(g,g‚àíf)‚à£g‚ààœÄ‚Å¢(ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f))}.subscriptùíüùí´ùëìconditional-setùëîùëîùëìùëîùúãsubscriptùíüùí´ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)=\{(g,g-f)\mid g\in\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f% ))\}.caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) = { ( italic_g , italic_g - italic_f ) ‚à£ italic_g ‚àà italic_œÄ ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ) } . We now show that this is indeed a polyhedron, which arises as the intersection of two shifted copies of a cone.

Theorem 3.5.

The set ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí´ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) is a polyhedron that arises as the intersection of convex functions with an affine hyperplane Hf={(g,h)‚à£f=g‚àíh}subscriptùêªùëìconditional-setùëî‚Ñéùëìùëî‚ÑéH_{f}=\{(g,h)\mid f=g-h\}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { ( italic_g , italic_h ) ‚à£ italic_f = italic_g - italic_h }, namely ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)=(ùí±¬Øùí´+√óùí±¬Øùí´+)‚à©Hf.subscriptùíüùí´ùëìsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´superscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´subscriptùêªùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)=(\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}\times% \overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+})\cap H_{f}.caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) = ( over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT √ó over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚à© italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . Under the bijection œÄùúã\piitalic_œÄ, the decomposition polyhedron is the intersection of two shifted copies of the polyhedral cone ùí±¬Øùí´+superscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. More specifically, œÄ‚Å¢(ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f))=ùí±¬Øùí´+‚à©(ùí±¬Øùí´++f).ùúãsubscriptùíüùí´ùëìsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´superscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´ùëì\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))=\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}\cap% (\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}+f).italic_œÄ ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ) = over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à© ( over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_f ) .

Remark 3.6.

Under the isomorphism of Lemma 3.2, we identify ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí´ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) with the polyhedron {(wg,wh)‚ààùí≤ùí´+√óùí≤ùí´+‚à£wg‚àíwh=wf}conditional-setsubscriptùë§ùëîsubscriptùë§‚Ñésuperscriptsubscriptùí≤ùí´superscriptsubscriptùí≤ùí´subscriptùë§ùëîsubscriptùë§‚Ñésubscriptùë§ùëì\{(w_{g},w_{h})\in\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}\times\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}% ^{+}\mid w_{g}-w_{h}=w_{f}\}{ ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚àà caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT √ó caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à£ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } in ùí≤ùí´√óùí≤ùí´subscriptùí≤ùí´subscriptùí≤ùí´\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}\times\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT √ó caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and œÄ‚Å¢(ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f))ùúãsubscriptùíüùí´ùëì\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))italic_œÄ ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ) with the polyhedron {wg‚ààùí≤ùí´+‚à£wg‚â•wf}conditional-setsubscriptùë§ùëîsuperscriptsubscriptùí≤ùí´subscriptùë§ùëîsubscriptùë§ùëì\{w_{g}\in\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}\mid w_{g}\geq w_{f}\}{ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à£ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â• italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, where ùí≤ùí´+={w‚ààùí≤ùí´‚à£w‚â•0}superscriptsubscriptùí≤ùí´conditional-setùë§subscriptùí≤ùí´ùë§0\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}=\{w\in\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}\mid w\geq 0\}caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { italic_w ‚àà caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à£ italic_w ‚â• 0 }.

For the remainder of this section, we analyze the faces of the polyhedron ùí±¬Øùí´+superscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in terms of the properties of the corresponding decompositions.

Definition 3.7.

A decomposition (g,h)‚ààùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)ùëî‚Ñésubscriptùíüùí´ùëì(g,h)\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)( italic_g , italic_h ) ‚àà caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) is called reduced, if there is no convex function œï‚ààùí±¬Øùí´+‚àñ{0}italic-œïsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´0\phi\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}\setminus\{0\}italic_œï ‚àà over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àñ { 0 } such that g‚àíœïùëîitalic-œïg-\phiitalic_g - italic_œï and h‚àíœï‚Ñéitalic-œïh-\phiitalic_h - italic_œï are both convex.

If a decomposition is not reduced, then we can obtain a ‚Äúbetter‚Äù decomposition by simultaneously simplifying both gùëîgitalic_g and h‚Ñéhitalic_h through subtracting a convex function œïitalic-œï\phiitalic_œï. Hence, it makes sense to put a special emphasis on reduced decompositions. Conveniently, the following theorem links this notion to the geometry of ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí´ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ).

Theorem 3.8.

A decomposition (g,h)‚ààùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)ùëî‚Ñésubscriptùíüùí´ùëì(g,h)\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)( italic_g , italic_h ) ‚àà caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) is reduced if and only if (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) is contained in a bounded face of ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí´ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ).

Definition 3.9.

We call a convex function g‚ààùí±¬Øùí´+ùëîsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´g\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}italic_g ‚àà over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT a coarsening of another convex function g‚Ä≤‚ààùí±¬Øùí´+superscriptùëî‚Ä≤superscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´g^{\prime}\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if the unique coarsest polyhedral complex ùí´gsubscriptùí´ùëî\mathcal{P}_{g}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of gùëîgitalic_g is a coarsening of the unique coarsest polyhedral complex ùí´g‚Ä≤subscriptùí´superscriptùëî‚Ä≤\mathcal{P}_{g^{\prime}}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For a pair of convex CPWL functions (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ), we call (g‚Ä≤,h‚Ä≤)superscriptùëî‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) a coarsening of (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) if g‚àíh=g‚Ä≤‚àíh‚Ä≤ùëî‚Ñésuperscriptùëî‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤g-h=g^{\prime}-h^{\prime}italic_g - italic_h = italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and gùëîgitalic_g and h‚Ñéhitalic_h are coarsenings of g‚Ä≤superscriptùëî‚Ä≤g^{\prime}italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT respectively. The coarsening is called non-trivial if (ùí´g,ùí´h)‚â†(ùí´g‚Ä≤,ùí´h‚Ä≤)subscriptùí´ùëîsubscriptùí´‚Ñésubscriptùí´superscriptùëî‚Ä≤subscriptùí´superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤(\mathcal{P}_{g},\mathcal{P}_{h})\neq(\mathcal{P}_{g^{\prime}},\mathcal{P}_{h^% {\prime}})( caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚â† ( caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). For a function f‚ààùí±ùí´ùëìsubscriptùí±ùí´f\in\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_f ‚àà caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, let suppùí´‚Å°(f)={œÉ‚ààùí´n‚àí1‚à£wg‚Å¢(œÉ)‚â†0}subscriptsuppùí´ùëìconditional-setùúésuperscriptùí´ùëõ1subscriptùë§ùëîùúé0\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)=\{\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}\mid w_{g}(% \sigma)\neq 0\}roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) = { italic_œÉ ‚àà caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à£ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œÉ ) ‚â† 0 }.

Lemma 3.10.

A convex function g‚Ä≤‚ààùí±¬Øùí´+superscriptùëî‚Ä≤superscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´g^{\prime}\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a coarsening of g‚ààùí±¬Øùí´+ùëîsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´g\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}italic_g ‚àà over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if and only if suppùí´‚Å°(g‚Ä≤)‚äÜsuppùí´‚Å°(g)subscriptsuppùí´superscriptùëî‚Ä≤subscriptsuppùí´ùëî\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}({g^{\prime}})\subseteq\operatorname{supp}_{% \mathcal{P}}(g)roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚äÜ roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ). The coarsening is non-trivial if and only if suppùí´‚Å°(g‚Ä≤)‚äÇsuppùí´‚Å°(g)subscriptsuppùí´superscriptùëî‚Ä≤subscriptsuppùí´ùëî\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}({g^{\prime}})\subset\operatorname{supp}_{% \mathcal{P}}(g)roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚äÇ roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ).

Theorem 3.11.

Let (g,h)‚ààùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)ùëî‚Ñésubscriptùíüùí´ùëì(g,h)\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)( italic_g , italic_h ) ‚àà caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ), then the following three statements are equivalent:

  1. 1.

    There is no non-trivial coarsening of (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ).

  2. 2.

    (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) is a vertex of ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí´ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ).

  3. 3.

    (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) is a vertex of ùíüùí¨‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí¨ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{Q}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) for all polyhedral complexes ùí¨ùí¨\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q compatible with gùëîgitalic_g and h‚Ñéhitalic_h.

Definition 3.12.

A decomposition (g,h)‚ààùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)ùëî‚Ñésubscriptùíüùí´ùëì(g,h)\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)( italic_g , italic_h ) ‚àà caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) is called minimal, if it is not dominated by any other decomposition, that is, if there is no other decomposition (g‚Ä≤,h‚Ä≤)‚ààùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)superscriptùëî‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤subscriptùíüùí´ùëì(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚àà caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) where g‚Ä≤superscriptùëî‚Ä≤g^{\prime}italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has at most as many pieces as gùëîgitalic_g, h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has at most as many pieces as h‚Ñéhitalic_h, and one of the two has stricly fewer pieces. See Figure 2 in Section A.2 for a visualization.

The number of pieces relates to the notion of monomial complexity studied in Tran & Wang (2024), and a minimal decomposition translates to a decomposition which is minimal with respect to monomial complexity. We now give a geometric interpretation of this property in term of ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí´ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ).

Theorem 3.13.

A minimal decomposition (g,h)‚ààùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)ùëî‚Ñésubscriptùíüùí´ùëì(g,h)\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)( italic_g , italic_h ) ‚àà caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) is always a vertex of ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí´ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ).

This theorem implies a simple finite procedure to find a minimal decomposition: enumerate all the vertices of ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí´ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) and choose one satisfying Definition 3.12. It also suggests the following important special case.

Proposition 3.14.

If ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí´ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ), or equivalently œÄ‚Å¢(ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f))ùúãsubscriptùíüùí´ùëì\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))italic_œÄ ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ), has a unique vertex, then this vertex corresponds to the unique minimal decomposition within ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí´ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ).

We now demonstrate that this case is not only convenient, but also it indeed arises for important classes of functions. To this end, recall that œÄ‚Å¢(ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f))=ùí±¬Øùí´+‚à©(ùí±¬Øùí´++f)ùúãsubscriptùíüùí´ùëìsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´superscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´ùëì\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))=\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}\cap% (\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}+f)italic_œÄ ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ) = over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à© ( over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_f ), where ùí±¬Øùí´+superscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a convex, pointed polyhedral cone. In Lemma E.6, we give some sufficient conditions for such intersections of shifted cones to yield a polyhedron with a unique vertex. Moreover, the support of a decomposition can serve as certificate to verify if a decomposition is a unique vertex, and hence minimal. For f‚ààùí±¬Øùí´+ùëìsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´f\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}italic_f ‚àà over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, let suppùí´+‚Å°(f)‚âî{œÉ‚ààùí´‚à£wf‚Å¢(œÉ)>0}‚âîsuperscriptsubscriptsuppùí´ùëìconditional-setùúéùí´subscriptùë§ùëìùúé0\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}(f)\coloneqq\{\sigma\in\mathcal{P}\mid w_% {f}(\sigma)>0\}roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ‚âî { italic_œÉ ‚àà caligraphic_P ‚à£ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œÉ ) > 0 } and suppùí´‚àí‚Å°(f)‚âî{œÉ‚ààùí´‚à£wf‚Å¢(œÉ)<0}‚âîsuperscriptsubscriptsuppùí´ùëìconditional-setùúéùí´subscriptùë§ùëìùúé0\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}^{-}(f)\coloneqq\{\sigma\in\mathcal{P}\mid w_% {f}(\sigma)<0\}roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ‚âî { italic_œÉ ‚àà caligraphic_P ‚à£ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œÉ ) < 0 }.

Proposition 3.15.

If for f‚ààùí±¬Øùí´ùëìsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´f\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_f ‚àà over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, there are g,h‚ààùí±¬Øùí´+ùëî‚Ñésuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´g,h\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}italic_g , italic_h ‚àà over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that f=g‚àíhùëìùëî‚Ñéf=g-hitalic_f = italic_g - italic_h and supp+‚Å°(f)=suppùí´‚Å°(g)superscriptsuppùëìsubscriptsuppùí´ùëî\operatorname{supp}^{+}(f)=\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}(g)roman_supp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_f ) = roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ) as well as supp‚àí‚Å°(f)=suppùí´‚Å°(h)superscriptsuppùëìsubscriptsuppùí´‚Ñé\operatorname{supp}^{-}(f)=\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}(h)roman_supp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_f ) = roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_h ), then (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) is the unique vertex of ùíüùí¨‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí¨ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{Q}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) for every regular complete complex ùí¨ùí¨\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q compatible with fùëìfitalic_f. In this case, gùëîgitalic_g and h‚Ñéhitalic_h have at most as many pieces as fùëìfitalic_f.

While Proposition 3.15 sounds technical, it is powerful as it allows us to prove that important functions satisfy the condition of Proposition 3.14.

Definition 3.16.

A hyperplane function with kùëòkitalic_k hyperplanes is a function f:‚Ñùn‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëì‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëõ‚Ñùf\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R given by f‚Å¢(x)=‚àëi‚àà[k]Œªi‚ãÖmax‚Å°{‚ü®x,ai‚ü©+bi,‚ü®x,ci‚ü©+di}ùëìùë•subscriptùëñdelimited-[]ùëò‚ãÖsubscriptùúÜùëñùë•subscriptùëéùëñsubscriptùëèùëñùë•subscriptùëêùëñsubscriptùëëùëñf(x)=\sum_{i\in[k]}\lambda_{i}\cdot\max\{\langle x,a_{i}\rangle+b_{i},\langle x% ,c_{i}\rangle+d_{i}\}italic_f ( italic_x ) = ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ italic_k ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ roman_max { ‚ü® italic_x , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚ü® italic_x , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© + italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } for any ai,ci‚àà‚Ñùn,bi,di,Œªi‚àà‚Ñù,i‚àà[k]formulae-sequencesubscriptùëéùëñsubscriptùëêùëñsuperscript‚ÑùùëõsubscriptùëèùëñsubscriptùëëùëñsubscriptùúÜùëñ‚Ñùùëñdelimited-[]ùëòa_{i},c_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{n},b_{i},d_{i},\lambda_{i}\in\mathbb{R},i\in[k]italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R , italic_i ‚àà [ italic_k ].

Hyperplane functions are precisely the functions that are computable by a ReLU neural network with one hidden layer and appear in this context as 2-term max functions (Hertrich et al. (2021)). They also coincide with functions computable with the hinging hyperplane model (Breiman (1993); Wang & Sun (2005)). Moreover, in Example D.14 we will see that hyperplane functions include continuous extensions of cut functions.

Definition 3.17.

The kùëòkitalic_k-th order statistic is the function f:‚Ñùn‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëì‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëõ‚Ñùf\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R that returns the kùëòkitalic_k-th largest entry of an input vector x‚àà‚Ñùnùë•superscript‚Ñùùëõx\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_x ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For k=‚åän2‚åãùëòùëõ2k=\lfloor\frac{n}{2}\rflooritalic_k = ‚åä divide start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚åã, this coincides with the median.

In Section A.3, we show that the conditions of Propositions 3.14 and 3.15 are indeed fulfilled for both, hyperplane functions and kùëòkitalic_k-th order statistics. This shows that they admit decompositions with at most as many pieces as the function itself.

Theorem 3.8 characterizes the reduced decompositions as bounded faces and Proposition 3.15 provides a condition that can identify a given decomposition as the minimal one. The natural follow-up question is how to find these decompositions. In the following, we show that this can be done via linear programming over the decomposition polyhedron.

Theorem 3.18.

A decomposition in œÄ‚Å¢(ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f))=ùí±¬Øùí´+‚à©(f+ùí±¬Øùí´+)ùúãsubscriptùíüùí´ùëìsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´ùëìsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))=\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}\cap% (f+\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+})italic_œÄ ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ) = over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à© ( italic_f + over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is reduced if and only if it is the minimizer in œÄ‚Å¢(ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f))ùúãsubscriptùíüùí´ùëì\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))italic_œÄ ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ) of a direction contained in the interior of the dual cone of ùí±¬Øùí´+superscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In particular, if œÄ‚Å¢(ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f))ùúãsubscriptùíüùí´ùëì\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))italic_œÄ ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ) has a single vertex, then the unique minimizer is the unique reduced and minimal decomposition. Under the isomorphism to ùí≤ùí´subscriptùí≤ùí´\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the direction uùë¢uitalic_u can be chosen as u‚Å¢(œÉ)=1ùë¢ùúé1u(\sigma)=1italic_u ( italic_œÉ ) = 1 for all œÉùúé\sigmaitalic_œÉ.

4 Analysis of existing decompositions

Constructions of decompositions of CPWL functions as difference of two convex functions have appeared in many contexts. In this section, we relate some of these existing constructions to our framework. Moreover, we provide a counterexample to a construction which was proposed by Tran & Wang (2024) to obtain a minimal decomposition in general dimensions.

4.1 Hyperplane extension and local maxima decomposition

The literature contains a variety of different constructions to decompose a CPWL function. It is worth noting, however, that these constructions usually follow one of two main themes. The first theme is to construct (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) in a way such that they are compatible with the complex ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P that arises by extending the codimension-1111 faces of ùí´fsubscriptùí´ùëì\mathcal{P}_{f}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to hyperplanes, see e.g. Zalgaller (2000) and Schl√ºter & Darup (2021). The second theme is to exploit the properties of the lattice representation of a CPWL function (Wang, 2004).

Both of these themes were already illustrated by Kripfganz & Schulze (1987), and we describe their constructions in Appendix B as Construction B.1 (‚Äúhyperplane extensions‚Äù) and Construction B.2 (‚Äúlocal maxima decomposition‚Äù). In Section B.1, we show that for the functions that compute the kùëòkitalic_k-th order statistic, both constructions do not yield the unique minimal decompositions, which exist by Proposition 3.14. This implies the following result.

Proposition 4.1.

There is a function CPWL function fùëìfitalic_f such that constructions B.1 and B.2 do not provide a vertex of ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí´ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) for any regular polyhedral complex ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P compatible with fùëìfitalic_f.

Moreover, Proposition B.3 shows that the suboptimality of the existing decompositions in the literature is not caused by the concrete construction method, but rather by the polyhedral complexes underlying these methods.

4.2 Minimal decompositions

A construction for a unique minimal decomposition for certain CPWL functions fùëìfitalic_f in dimension 2222 was presented by Tran & Wang (2024), by introducing a single new 1111-dimensional face to ùí´fsubscriptùí´ùëì\mathcal{P}_{f}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and an adapted weight function to satisfy the balancing condition.

Their approach builds on a duality theory between positively homogeneous convex CPWL functions and Newton polytopes. A CPWL function fùëìfitalic_f is positively homogeneous if f‚Å¢(0)=0ùëì00f(0)=0italic_f ( 0 ) = 0 and ùí´fsubscriptùí´ùëì\mathcal{P}_{f}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a polyhedral fan. Such functions are the support functions of their Newton polytopes, as we describe in more detail in Section C.1; see also Joswig (2021, Section 1.2) and Maclagan & Sturmfels (2015, Chapter 2).

Based on their 2222-dimensional construction, Tran & Wang (2024) propose a procedure to reduce the nùëõnitalic_n-dimensional case to 2222-dimensions via projections, which we describe in Construction C.2 in Section C.2. The final step in this procedure is to construct a global function in nùëõnitalic_n dimensions by ‚Äúgluing together‚Äù the projections. In Example C.3 we illustrate that this final step is not always well-defined. Our conclusion is that the construction by Tran & Wang (2024) does not extend beyond the 2222-dimensional case, leaving it an open problem to find any finite algorithm that guarantees to return a minimal decomposition without fixing an underlying polyhedral complex. Note that for any fixed underlying polyhedral complex, Theorem 3.13 implies a finite algorithm by enumerating the vertices of the decomposition polyhedron, as discussed earlier.

5 Submodular Functions

We demonstrate that a special case of our framework is to decompose a general set function into a difference of submodular set funtions and translate our results to this setting. Such decompositions are a popular approach to solve optimization problems as disussed in the introduction. Here, we sketch the idea, all details can be found in Appendix D. Let the polyhedral complex ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P be induced by the braid arrangement, that is, the hyperplane arrangement consisting of the (n2)binomialùëõ2\binom{n}{2}( FRACOP start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) hyperplanes xi=xjsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëóx_{i}=x_{j}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with 1‚â§i<j‚â§n1ùëñùëóùëõ1\leq i<j\leq n1 ‚â§ italic_i < italic_j ‚â§ italic_n, and let ‚Ñ±nsubscript‚Ñ±ùëõ\mathcal{F}_{n}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the vector space of set functions from 2[n]superscript2delimited-[]ùëõ2^{[n]}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R}blackboard_R.

Proposition 5.1.

The mapping Œ¶Œ¶\Phiroman_Œ¶ that maps f‚ààùí±ùí´ùëìsubscriptùí±ùí´f\in\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_f ‚àà caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to the set function F‚Å¢(S)=f‚Å¢(ùüôS)ùêπùëÜùëìsubscript1ùëÜF(S)=f(\mathds{1}_{S})italic_F ( italic_S ) = italic_f ( blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where ùüôS=‚àëi‚ààSeisubscript1ùëÜsubscriptùëñùëÜsubscriptùëíùëñ\mathds{1}_{S}=\sum_{i\in S}e_{i}blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, is a vector space isomorphism.

Conversely, starting with a set function FùêπFitalic_F, then f=Œ¶‚àí1‚Å¢(F)ùëìsuperscriptŒ¶1ùêπf=\Phi^{-1}(F)italic_f = roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_F ) is by definition a continuous extension of FùêπFitalic_F, which is known as the Lov√°sz extension (Lov√°sz, 1983). The Lov√°sz extension is an important concept in the theory and practice of submodular function optimization as it provides a link between discrete submodular functions and continuous convex functions.

Definition 5.2.

A set function F:2[n]‚Üí‚Ñù:ùêπ‚Üísuperscript2delimited-[]ùëõ‚ÑùF\colon 2^{[n]}\to\mathbb{R}italic_F : 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R is called submodular if F‚Å¢(A)+F‚Å¢(B)‚â•F‚Å¢(A‚à™B)+F‚Å¢(A‚à©B)ùêπùê¥ùêπùêµùêπùê¥ùêµùêπùê¥ùêµF(A)+F(B)\geq F(A\cup B)+F(A\cap B)italic_F ( italic_A ) + italic_F ( italic_B ) ‚â• italic_F ( italic_A ‚à™ italic_B ) + italic_F ( italic_A ‚à© italic_B ) for all A,B‚äÜ[n]ùê¥ùêµdelimited-[]ùëõA,B\subseteq[n]italic_A , italic_B ‚äÜ [ italic_n ]. FùêπFitalic_F is called modular if equality holds for all A,B‚äÜ[n]ùê¥ùêµdelimited-[]ùëõA,B\subseteq[n]italic_A , italic_B ‚äÜ [ italic_n ].

Since a set function FùêπFitalic_F is submodular if and only if its Lov√°sz extension f=Œ¶‚àí1‚Å¢(F)ùëìsuperscriptŒ¶1ùêπf=\Phi^{-1}(F)italic_f = roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_F ) is convex (Lov√°sz (1983)), we can specialize 1.1 in the setting of this section as follows.

Problem 5.3.

Given a set function F‚àà‚Ñ±nùêπsubscript‚Ñ±ùëõF\in\mathcal{F}_{n}italic_F ‚àà caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, how to decompose it into a difference of submodular set functions such that their Lov√°sz extensions have as few pieces as possible?

Having a Lov√°sz extension with few pieces is desirable because it allows the submodular function to be stored and accessed efficiently during computational tasks. Moreover, as we argue in Appendix D, for accordingly normalized submodular functions, the number of pieces of the Lov√°sz extension is precisely the number of vertices of the base polytope, which, in turn, is precisely the Newton polytope of the Lov√°sz extension.

As 5.3 is a special case of 1.1, we can translate our results from Section 3 to the setting of submodular functions.

Corollary 5.4 (informal).

The set of decompositions of a general set function into a difference of submodular functions (modulo modular functions) is a polyhedron that arises as the intersection of two shifted copies of the cone of submodular functions. In analogy to our general results, the irreducible decompositions correspond precisely to the bounded faces of that polyhedron and every minimal decomposition is a vertex.

Example D.14 shows that the Lov√°sz extensions of cut functions are hyperplane functions and thus admit a unique minimal decomposition into submodular functions, which are themselves cut functions. In particular, the Lov√°sz extensions of the decomposition have at most as many pieces as the Lov√°sz extensions of the original cut function.

6 Neural Network Constructions

In this section we consider the following question: Given a CPWL function f:‚Ñùn‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëì‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëõ‚Ñùf\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R with qùëûqitalic_q pieces and kùëòkitalic_k affine components, what is the necessary depth, width, and size of a neural network exactly representing this function? To this end, we first discuss the necessary background on neural networks and known results on neural complexity. We then prove better results for the case of fùëìfitalic_f being convex. Finally, we extend these results to nonconvex functions by writing them as a difference of convex functions.

6.1 Background

For a number of hidden layers d‚â•0ùëë0d\geq 0italic_d ‚â• 0, a neural network with rectified linear unit (ReLU) activiations is defined by a sequence of d+1ùëë1d+1italic_d + 1 affine transformations Ti:‚Ñùni‚àí1‚Üí‚Ñùni:subscriptùëáùëñ‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùsubscriptùëõùëñ1superscript‚ÑùsubscriptùëõùëñT_{i}:\mathbb{R}^{n_{i-1}}\to\mathbb{R}^{n_{i}}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, i‚àà[d+1]ùëñdelimited-[]ùëë1i\in[d+1]italic_i ‚àà [ italic_d + 1 ]. We assume that n0=nsubscriptùëõ0ùëõn_{0}=nitalic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_n and nd+1=1subscriptùëõùëë11n_{d+1}=1italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1. If œÉùúé\sigmaitalic_œÉ denotes the function that computes the ReLU function x‚Ü¶max‚Å°{x,0}maps-toùë•ùë•0x\mapsto\max\{x,0\}italic_x ‚Ü¶ roman_max { italic_x , 0 } in each component, the neural network is said to compute the function f:‚Ñùn‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëì‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëõ‚Ñùf\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R given by f=Td+1‚àòœÉ‚àòTd‚àòœÉ‚àò‚ãØ‚àòœÉ‚àòT1ùëìsubscriptùëáùëë1ùúésubscriptùëáùëëùúé‚ãØùúésubscriptùëá1f=T_{d+1}\circ\sigma\circ T_{d}\circ\sigma\circ\dots\circ\sigma\circ T_{1}italic_f = italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àò italic_œÉ ‚àò italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àò italic_œÉ ‚àò ‚ãØ ‚àò italic_œÉ ‚àò italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We say that the neural network has depth d+1ùëë1d+1italic_d + 1, width maxi‚àà[d]‚Å°nisubscriptùëñdelimited-[]ùëësubscriptùëõùëñ\max_{i\in[d]}n_{i}roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ italic_d ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and size ‚àëi‚àà[d]nisubscriptùëñdelimited-[]ùëësubscriptùëõùëñ\sum_{i\in[d]}n_{i}‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ italic_d ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

It is well-known that the maximum of nùëõnitalic_n numbers can be computed with depth ‚åàlog2‚Å°n‚åâ+1subscript2ùëõ1\lceil\log_{2}n\rceil+1‚åà roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ‚åâ + 1 and overall size ùí™‚Å¢(n)ùí™ùëõ\mathcal{O}(n)caligraphic_O ( italic_n ) (Arora et al., 2018). This simple fact has been used in the literature to deduce exact representations of CPWL functions with neural networks from known representations of CPWL functions. We would like to focus on two of them here, which are in a sense incomparable. The first one goes back to Hertrich et al. (2021) and builds upon ideas from Wang & Sun (2005). We present it here in a slightly stronger form.

Theorem 6.1.

Every CPWL function f:‚Ñùn‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëì‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëõ‚Ñùf\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R with kùëòkitalic_k affine components can be represented by a neural network with depth ‚åàlog2‚Å°(n+1)‚åâ+1subscript2ùëõ11\lceil\log_{2}(n+1)\rceil+1‚åà roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_n + 1 ) ‚åâ + 1 and overall size ùí™‚Å¢(kn+1)ùí™superscriptùëòùëõ1\mathcal{O}(k^{n+1})caligraphic_O ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

The second one goes back to Chen et al. (2022) and is based on the lattice representation of CPWL functions, compare Tarela & Martinez (1999).

Theorem 6.2 ((Chen et al., 2022)).

Every CPWL function f:‚Ñùn‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëì‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëõ‚Ñùf\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R with qùëûqitalic_q pieces and kùëòkitalic_k affine components can be represented by a neural network with depth ‚åàlog2‚Å°p‚åâ+‚åàlog2‚Å°q‚åâ+1subscript2ùëùsubscript2ùëû1\lceil\log_{2}p\rceil+\lceil\log_{2}q\rceil+1‚åà roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ‚åâ + ‚åà roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q ‚åâ + 1 and overall size ùí™‚Å¢(k‚Å¢q)ùí™ùëòùëû\mathcal{O}(kq)caligraphic_O ( italic_k italic_q ).

As noted before, one can assume that n<k‚â§qùëõùëòùëûn<k\leq qitalic_n < italic_k ‚â§ italic_q, since otherwise we could affinely project to a lower dimension without losing information. In fact, one would usually assume that the input dimension nùëõnitalic_n is much lower than the number of affine components kùëòkitalic_k. Therefore, Theorem 6.1 provides the better representation in terms of depth, while Theorem 6.2 provides the better representation in terms of size. However, both theorems are kind of inflexible for the user, dictating a certing depth and providing only these two specific options. So, the naturally occuring question is: can we somehow freely choose a depth and trade depth against size in these representations? In other words: can we smoothly interpolate between the low-depth high-size representation of Theorem 6.1 and the low-size high-depth representation of Theorem 6.2? In the remaining section we present results that achieve this to some extent.

6.2 New Constructions for the Convex Case

In this part we prove that we can achieve the desired tradeoff easily in the convex case by mixing the two representations of Theorem 6.1 and Theorem 6.2.

Theorem 6.3.

Every convex CPWL function f:‚Ñùn‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëì‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëõ‚Ñùf\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R with q=kùëûùëòq=kitalic_q = italic_k affine components can be represented by a neural network with depth ‚åàlog2‚Å°(n+1)‚åâ+‚åàlog2‚Å°r‚åâ+1subscript2ùëõ1subscript2ùëü1\lceil\log_{2}(n+1)\rceil+\lceil\log_{2}r\rceil+1‚åà roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_n + 1 ) ‚åâ + ‚åà roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r ‚åâ + 1 and overall size ùí™‚Å¢(r‚Å¢sn+1)ùí™ùëüsuperscriptùë†ùëõ1\mathcal{O}(rs^{n+1})caligraphic_O ( italic_r italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), for any free choice of parameters rùëüritalic_r and sùë†sitalic_s with r‚Å¢s‚â•kùëüùë†ùëòrs\geq kitalic_r italic_s ‚â• italic_k.

In order to see how this provides a tradeoff between the representations of Theorem 6.1 and Theorem 6.2, it is worth looking at the extreme cases. If we choose r=1ùëü1r=1italic_r = 1 and s=kùë†ùëòs=kitalic_s = italic_k, we exactly obtain the bounds from Theorem 6.1. On the other hand, if we choose r=kùëüùëòr=kitalic_r = italic_k and s=1ùë†1s=1italic_s = 1, we obtain a neural network with depth ùí™‚Å¢(log‚Å°k)ùí™ùëò\mathcal{O}(\log k)caligraphic_O ( roman_log italic_k ) and size ùí™‚Å¢(k)ùí™ùëò\mathcal{O}(k)caligraphic_O ( italic_k ), which is qualitatively close to the bounds of Theorem 6.2. In fact, the even better size bound stems from the fact that our construction heavily relies on convexity.

In conclusion, by choosing an appropriate rùëüritalic_r (and corresponding sùë†sitalic_s), the user can freely decide how to trade depth against size in neural network representations and thereby interpolate between the two extreme representations of Theorem 6.1 and Theorem 6.2.

6.3 Extension to the Nonconvex Case

The construction of Theorem 6.3 provides a nice blueprint of how to interpolate between Theorem 6.1 and Theorem 6.2, but it has the big limitation that it only works in the convex case. Simply mixing the two known representations of Theorems 6.1 and 6.2 does not appear to work in the nonconvex case, as one cannot as easily identify groups of affine components that can be treated separately.

Instead we propose a different approach: given a CPWL function, first split it into a difference of two convex ones and then apply Theorem 6.3 to these two functions. To do this efficiently, it requires to find a good answer to 1.1.

As discussed in this paper, it is quite challenging to give a satisfying answer to 1.1 in full generality, but there are special cases, where we do have a good answer; see Section 3. For example, we obtain the following result by combining Theorem 6.3 with Lemma E.3.

Corollary 6.4.

Let f:‚Ñùn‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëì‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëõ‚Ñùf\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R be a CPWL function that is compatible with a regular polyhedral complex ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P with q~=|ùí´n|~ùëûsuperscriptùí´ùëõ\tilde{q}=\lvert\mathcal{P}^{n}\rvertover~ start_ARG italic_q end_ARG = | caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | full-dimensional polyhedra. Then, fùëìfitalic_f can be represented by a neural network with depth ‚åàlog2‚Å°(n+1)‚åâ+‚åàlog2‚Å°r‚åâ+1subscript2ùëõ1subscript2ùëü1\lceil\log_{2}(n+1)\rceil+\lceil\log_{2}r\rceil+1‚åà roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_n + 1 ) ‚åâ + ‚åà roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r ‚åâ + 1 and overall size ùí™‚Å¢(r‚Å¢sn+1)ùí™ùëüsuperscriptùë†ùëõ1\mathcal{O}(rs^{n+1})caligraphic_O ( italic_r italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), for any free choice of parameters rùëüritalic_r and sùë†sitalic_s with r‚Å¢s‚â•q~ùëüùë†~ùëûrs\geq\tilde{q}italic_r italic_s ‚â• over~ start_ARG italic_q end_ARG.

For a given CPWL function fùëìfitalic_f, provided that one can find a regular polyhedral complex such that q~~ùëû\tilde{q}over~ start_ARG italic_q end_ARG is not much larger than the number of pieces qùëûqitalic_q, Corollary 6.4 does indeed provide a smooth tradeoff between Theorem 6.1 and Theorem 6.2 in the general, nonconvex case. As qùëûqitalic_q is the minimal number of fulldimensional polyhedra in any (potentially nonregular) polyhedral complex compatible with fùëìfitalic_f, the big question is how much of a restriction the assumption of regularity might be.

7 Open Problems

From the theoretical perspective, the maybe most dominant open question is the following precise version of 1.1.

Problem 7.1.

Given a CPWL function fùëìfitalic_f in dimension nùëõnitalic_n with qùëûqitalic_q pieces, does there always exist a decomposition f=g‚àíhùëìùëî‚Ñéf=g-hitalic_f = italic_g - italic_h such that the number of pieces of gùëîgitalic_g and h‚Ñéhitalic_h is polynomial in nùëõnitalic_n and qùëûqitalic_q?

Note that by definition, fùëìfitalic_f is compatible with a polyhedral complex ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P with |ùí´n|=qsuperscriptùí´ùëõùëû\lvert\mathcal{P}^{n}\rvert=q| caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | = italic_q. To answer 7.1 positively, by Lemma E.3 it would be sufficient to find a regular polyhedral complex ùí¨ùí¨\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q with |ùí¨n|=poly‚Å¢(n,q)superscriptùí¨ùëõpolyùëõùëû\lvert\mathcal{Q}^{n}\rvert=\mathrm{poly}(n,q)| caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | = roman_poly ( italic_n , italic_q ) that is a refinement of ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P. Conversely, if we can answer 7.1 positively, then the underlying complex of g+hùëî‚Ñég+hitalic_g + italic_h would give us such a regular complex ùí¨ùí¨\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q. Therefore, to solve 7.1, one needs to answer the following question: given an arbitrary complete polyhedral complex ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P, what is the ‚Äúcoarsest‚Äù refinement of ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P that is regular? A positive answer to 7.1 would have useful consequences for our two applications in the context of (submodular) set function optimization and neural network representations. However, also a negative answer would be equally interesting.

One possible approach to resolve 7.1 could be to analyze which objective direction according to Theorem 3.18 leads to a good vertex of the decomposition polyhedron and prove theoretical properties about that vertex. The same theorem might also be key to developing algorithms that find good decompositions with linear programming. Generally, while beyond the scope of this paper, turning any of our insights into practical algorithms, preferably with theoretical guarantees, is a broad avenue for future research.
