In particular, ùí±¬Øùí´=span‚Å°(ùí±¬Øùí´+)subscript¬Øùí±ùí´spansuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}=\operatorname{span}(\overline{\mathcal{V}% }_{\mathcal{P}}^{+})over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_span ( over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

Proof.

Let f‚ààùí±ùí´ùëìsubscriptùí±ùí´f\in\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_f ‚àà caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be an arbirtary function. Since ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P is regular, by definition there exists a convex function g‚ààùí±ùí´ùëîsubscriptùí±ùí´g\in\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{P}}italic_g ‚àà caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that ùí´=ùí´gùí´subscriptùí´ùëî\mathcal{P}=\mathcal{P}_{g}caligraphic_P = caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Proposition 3.3 implies that wg‚Å¢(œÉ)>0subscriptùë§ùëîùúé0w_{g}(\sigma)>0italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œÉ ) > 0 for all œÉ‚ààùí´n‚àí1ùúésuperscriptùí´ùëõ1\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}italic_œÉ ‚àà caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For sufficiently large Œª>0ùúÜ0\lambda>0italic_Œª > 0, it follows that wf+Œª‚Å¢g‚â•0subscriptùë§ùëìùúÜùëî0w_{f+\lambda g}\geq 0italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f + italic_Œª italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â• 0 and thus f=(f+Œª‚Å¢g)‚àíŒª‚Å¢gùëìùëìùúÜùëîùúÜùëîf=(f+\lambda g)-\lambda gitalic_f = ( italic_f + italic_Œª italic_g ) - italic_Œª italic_g is a representation of fùëìfitalic_f as a difference of two compatible, convex functions, as desired. ‚àé

E.7 Proof Theorem 3.5

Proof.

For the set of decompositions holds

ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)={(g,h)‚à£g‚ààùí±¬Øùí´+,h‚ààùí±¬Øùí´+,f=g‚àíh}=(ùí±¬Øùí´+√óùí±¬Øùí´+)‚à©Hf.subscriptùíüùí´ùëìconditional-setùëî‚Ñéformulae-sequenceùëîsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´formulae-sequence‚Ñésuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´ùëìùëî‚Ñésuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´superscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´subscriptùêªùëì\displaystyle\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)=\{(g,h)\mid g\in\overline{\mathcal{V% }}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+},h\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+},f=g-h\}=(% \overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}\times\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal% {P}}^{+})\cap H_{f}.caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) = { ( italic_g , italic_h ) ‚à£ italic_g ‚àà over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h ‚àà over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_f = italic_g - italic_h } = ( over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT √ó over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚à© italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

For the projection we have

œÄ‚Å¢(ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f))=œÄ‚Å¢({(g,g‚àíf)‚à£g‚ààùí±¬Øùí´+,g‚àíf‚ààùí±¬Øùí´+})={g‚à£g‚ààùí±¬Øùí´+,g‚ààf+ùí±¬Øùí´+}=ùí±¬Øùí´+‚à©(f+ùí±¬Øùí´+).ùúãsubscriptùíüùí´ùëìùúãconditional-setùëîùëîùëìformulae-sequenceùëîsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´ùëîùëìsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´conditional-setùëîformulae-sequenceùëîsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´ùëîùëìsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´superscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´ùëìsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´\displaystyle\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))=\pi(\{(g,g-f)\mid g\in\overline% {\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+},g-f\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}% \})=\{g\mid g\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+},g\in f+\overline{% \mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}\}=\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}\cap(% f+\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}).italic_œÄ ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ) = italic_œÄ ( { ( italic_g , italic_g - italic_f ) ‚à£ italic_g ‚àà over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_g - italic_f ‚àà over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) = { italic_g ‚à£ italic_g ‚àà over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_g ‚àà italic_f + over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } = over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à© ( italic_f + over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .

‚àé

E.8 Proof of Theorem 3.8

The statement follows from a more general statement about polyhedra. Recall that any polyhedron PùëÉPitalic_P can written as the Minkowski sum

P=Q+C={q+c‚à£q‚ààQ,c‚ààC}ùëÉùëÑùê∂conditional-setùëûùëêformulae-sequenceùëûùëÑùëêùê∂P=Q+C=\{q+c\mid q\in Q,c\in C\}italic_P = italic_Q + italic_C = { italic_q + italic_c ‚à£ italic_q ‚àà italic_Q , italic_c ‚àà italic_C }

where QùëÑQitalic_Q is a bounded polytope, and Cùê∂Citalic_C a unique polyhedral cone, the recession cone of PùëÉPitalic_P.

Proposition E.4.

A point x‚ààPùë•ùëÉx\in Pitalic_x ‚àà italic_P is contained in a bounded face of PùëÉPitalic_P if and only if x‚àíc‚àâP‚Å¢‚àÄc‚ààC‚àñ{0}ùë•ùëêùëÉfor-allùëêùê∂0x-c\not\in P\ \forall c\in C\setminus\{0\}italic_x - italic_c ‚àâ italic_P ‚àÄ italic_c ‚àà italic_C ‚àñ { 0 }.

Proof.

Any face of the polyhedron PùëÉPitalic_P is of the form

Pu={x‚ààP‚à£‚ü®x,u‚ü©‚â•‚ü®y,u‚ü©‚Å¢‚àÄy‚ààP},superscriptùëÉùë¢conditional-setùë•ùëÉùë•ùë¢ùë¶ùë¢for-allùë¶ùëÉP^{u}=\{x\in P\mid\langle x,u\rangle\geq\langle y,u\rangle\ \forall y\in P\},italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { italic_x ‚àà italic_P ‚à£ ‚ü® italic_x , italic_u ‚ü© ‚â• ‚ü® italic_y , italic_u ‚ü© ‚àÄ italic_y ‚àà italic_P } ,

and for Minkowski sums holds Pu=Qu+CusuperscriptùëÉùë¢superscriptùëÑùë¢superscriptùê∂ùë¢P^{u}=Q^{u}+C^{u}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Let x‚ààPùë•ùëÉx\in Pitalic_x ‚àà italic_P be a point contained in a bounded face PusuperscriptùëÉùë¢P^{u}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of PùëÉPitalic_P. Since PusuperscriptùëÉùë¢P^{u}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is bounded, we have that Pu=Qu+CusuperscriptùëÉùë¢superscriptùëÑùë¢superscriptùê∂ùë¢P^{u}=Q^{u}+C^{u}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with Cu={0}superscriptùê∂ùë¢0C^{u}=\{0\}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { 0 } being the unique bounded face of Cùê∂Citalic_C. Thus, ‚ü®c,u‚ü©<‚ü®0,u‚ü©ùëêùë¢0ùë¢\langle c,u\rangle<\langle 0,u\rangle‚ü® italic_c , italic_u ‚ü© < ‚ü® 0 , italic_u ‚ü© for all c‚ààC‚àñ{0}ùëêùê∂0c\in C\setminus\{0\}italic_c ‚àà italic_C ‚àñ { 0 }. This implies that ‚ü®x‚àíc,u‚ü©=‚ü®x,u‚ü©‚àí‚ü®c,u‚ü©>‚ü®x,u‚ü©ùë•ùëêùë¢ùë•ùë¢ùëêùë¢ùë•ùë¢\langle x-c,u\rangle=\langle x,u\rangle-\langle c,u\rangle>\langle x,u\rangle‚ü® italic_x - italic_c , italic_u ‚ü© = ‚ü® italic_x , italic_u ‚ü© - ‚ü® italic_c , italic_u ‚ü© > ‚ü® italic_x , italic_u ‚ü© and therefore, by definition of PusuperscriptùëÉùë¢P^{u}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have that x‚àíc‚àâPùë•ùëêùëÉx-c\not\in Pitalic_x - italic_c ‚àâ italic_P.

Conversely, suppose that x‚ààPùë•ùëÉx\in Pitalic_x ‚àà italic_P is not contained in a bounded face. We want to show that there exists some direction c‚ààC‚àñ{0}ùëêùê∂0c\in C\setminus\{0\}italic_c ‚àà italic_C ‚àñ { 0 } such that x‚àíc‚ààPùë•ùëêùëÉx-c\in Pitalic_x - italic_c ‚àà italic_P. Since xùë•xitalic_x is not contained in a bounded face, it is contained in the relative interior of an unbounded face FùêπFitalic_F (where possibly F=PùêπùëÉF=Pitalic_F = italic_P). Since the face is unbounded, it contains a ray x+‚Ñù‚Å¢cùë•‚Ñùùëêx+\mathbb{R}citalic_x + blackboard_R italic_c for some direction c‚ààCùëêùê∂c\in Citalic_c ‚àà italic_C. On the other hand, since x‚ààint‚Å°(F)ùë•intùêπx\in\operatorname{int}(F)italic_x ‚àà roman_int ( italic_F ), we have that x‚àíŒµ‚Å¢c‚ààFùë•ùúÄùëêùêπx-\varepsilon c\in Fitalic_x - italic_Œµ italic_c ‚àà italic_F for Œµ>0ùúÄ0\varepsilon>0italic_Œµ > 0 small enough. As Cùê∂Citalic_C is a cone, we have that Œµ‚Å¢c‚ààCùúÄùëêùê∂\varepsilon c\in Citalic_Œµ italic_c ‚àà italic_C, which finishes the proof. ‚àé

Proof of Theorem 3.8.

Since œÄùúã\piitalic_œÄ induces a bijection between ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí´ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) and its image, this is also a bijection between bounded faces. By Theorem 3.5, œÄ‚Å¢(ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f))ùúãsubscriptùíüùí´ùëì\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))italic_œÄ ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ) is a polyhedron with recession cone ùí±¬Øùí´+superscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Proposition E.4 implies that gùëîgitalic_g is contained in a bounded face if and only if there exists no convex function œï‚ààùí±¬Øùí´+italic-œïsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´\phi\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}italic_œï ‚àà over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that g‚àíœï‚ààœÄ‚Å¢(ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f))ùëîitalic-œïùúãsubscriptùíüùí´ùëìg-\phi\in\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))italic_g - italic_œï ‚àà italic_œÄ ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ). Therefore, œÄ‚àí1‚Å¢(g)=(g,h),h=g‚àífformulae-sequencesuperscriptùúã1ùëîùëî‚Ñé‚Ñéùëîùëì\pi^{-1}(g)=(g,h),h=g-fitalic_œÄ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_g ) = ( italic_g , italic_h ) , italic_h = italic_g - italic_f is contained in a bounded face of ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí´ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) if and only if there is no œï‚ààùí±¬Øùí´+italic-œïsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´\phi\in\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}italic_œï ‚àà over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that (g‚àíœï,g‚àíf‚àíœï)=(g‚àíœï,h‚àíœï)‚àâùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)ùëîitalic-œïùëîùëìitalic-œïùëîitalic-œï‚Ñéitalic-œïsubscriptùíüùí´ùëì(g-\phi,g-f-\phi)=(g-\phi,h-\phi)\not\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)( italic_g - italic_œï , italic_g - italic_f - italic_œï ) = ( italic_g - italic_œï , italic_h - italic_œï ) ‚àâ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ). Since (g‚àíœï)‚àí(h‚àíœï)=fùëîitalic-œï‚Ñéitalic-œïùëì(g-\phi)-(h-\phi)=f( italic_g - italic_œï ) - ( italic_h - italic_œï ) = italic_f, this is equivalent to g‚àíœïùëîitalic-œïg-\phiitalic_g - italic_œï or h‚àíœï‚Ñéitalic-œïh-\phiitalic_h - italic_œï being nonconvex, i.e., (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) is reduced. ‚àé

E.9 Proof of Lemma 3.10

Proof.

First note that B‚Å¢(g)‚âî‚ãÉœÉ‚ààsuppùí´‚Å°(g)œÉ‚âîùêµùëîsubscriptùúésubscriptsuppùí´ùëîùúéB(g)\coloneqq\bigcup\limits_{\sigma\in\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}(g)}\sigmaitalic_B ( italic_g ) ‚âî ‚ãÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÉ ‚àà roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÉ are exactly the points where gùëîgitalic_g is not affine linear. Hence, the closures of the connected components of the complement of B‚Å¢(g)ùêµùëîB(g)italic_B ( italic_g ) are the maximal polyhedra of the unique coarsest polyhedral complex ùí´gsubscriptùí´ùëî\mathcal{P}_{g}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT compatible with gùëîgitalic_g.

Let suppùí´‚Å°(g‚Ä≤)‚äÜsuppùí´‚Å°(g)subscriptsuppùí´superscriptùëî‚Ä≤subscriptsuppùí´ùëî\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}({g^{\prime}})\subseteq\operatorname{supp}_{% \mathcal{P}}(g)roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚äÜ roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ). Equivalently, for the complement holds (‚Ñùn‚àñB‚Å¢(g))‚äÜ(‚Ñùn‚àñB‚Å¢(g‚Ä≤))superscript‚Ñùùëõùêµùëîsuperscript‚Ñùùëõùêµsuperscriptùëî‚Ä≤(\mathbb{R}^{n}\setminus B(g))\subseteq(\mathbb{R}^{n}\setminus B(g^{\prime}))( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àñ italic_B ( italic_g ) ) ‚äÜ ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àñ italic_B ( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ), and the same holds for the closures of the (open) connected components, i.e., the maximal faces in ùí´gnsubscriptsuperscriptùí´ùëõùëî\mathcal{P}^{n}_{g}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ùí´g‚Ä≤nsubscriptsuperscriptùí´ùëõsuperscriptùëî‚Ä≤\mathcal{P}^{n}_{g^{\prime}}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In other words, this is equivalent to that for every face P‚ààùí´gnùëÉsuperscriptsubscriptùí´ùëîùëõP\in\mathcal{P}_{g}^{n}italic_P ‚àà caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT there exists some P‚Ä≤‚ààùí´g‚Ä≤nsuperscriptùëÉ‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùí´superscriptùëî‚Ä≤ùëõP^{\prime}\in\mathcal{P}_{g^{\prime}}^{n}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that P‚äÜP‚Ä≤ùëÉsuperscriptùëÉ‚Ä≤P\subseteq P^{\prime}italic_P ‚äÜ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Thus, suppùí´‚Å°(g‚Ä≤)‚äÜsuppùí´‚Å°(g)subscriptsuppùí´superscriptùëî‚Ä≤subscriptsuppùí´ùëî\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}({g^{\prime}})\subseteq\operatorname{supp}_{% \mathcal{P}}(g)roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚äÜ roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ) if and only if ùí´g‚Ä≤subscriptùí´superscriptùëî‚Ä≤\mathcal{P}_{g^{\prime}}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a coarsening of ùí´gsubscriptùí´ùëî\mathcal{P}_{g}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

The coarsening is non-trivial if and only if there is a P‚Ä≤‚ààùí´g‚Ä≤nsuperscriptùëÉ‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùí´superscriptùëî‚Ä≤ùëõP^{\prime}\in\mathcal{P}_{g^{\prime}}^{n}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that there is no P‚ààùí´gnùëÉsuperscriptsubscriptùí´ùëîùëõP\in\mathcal{P}_{g}^{n}italic_P ‚àà caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with P‚Ä≤‚äÜPsuperscriptùëÉ‚Ä≤ùëÉP^{\prime}\subseteq Pitalic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚äÜ italic_P. This is the case if and only if there is a œÉ‚ààùí´gn‚àí1ùúésuperscriptsubscriptùí´ùëîùëõ1\sigma\in\mathcal{P}_{g}^{n-1}italic_œÉ ‚àà caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that intersects the interior of P‚Ä≤superscriptùëÉ‚Ä≤P^{\prime}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which occurs if and only if œÉ‚ààsuppùí´‚Å°(g)‚àñsuppùí´‚Å°(g‚Ä≤)ùúésubscriptsuppùí´ùëîsubscriptsuppùí´superscriptùëî‚Ä≤\sigma\in\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}(g)\setminus\operatorname{supp}_{% \mathcal{P}}(g^{\prime})italic_œÉ ‚àà roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ) ‚àñ roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). ‚àé

E.10 Proof of Theorem 3.11

We first prove the following proposition that relates coarsenings of the decompositions to inclusion relations of the minimal faces that contain the decompositions.

Proposition E.5.

For (g,h)‚ààùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)ùëî‚Ñésubscriptùíüùí´ùëì(g,h)\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)( italic_g , italic_h ) ‚àà caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ), let FùêπFitalic_F be the minimal face of ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí´ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) containing (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ). Then (g‚Ä≤,h‚Ä≤)superscriptùëî‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is a coarsening of (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) if and only if there is a face Gùê∫Gitalic_G of ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí´ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) with G‚äÜFùê∫ùêπG\subseteq Fitalic_G ‚äÜ italic_F such that (g‚Ä≤,h‚Ä≤)‚ààGsuperscriptùëî‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤ùê∫(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})\in G( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚àà italic_G. The coarsening is non-trivial if and only if F‚â†Gùêπùê∫F\neq Gitalic_F ‚â† italic_G.

Proof.

For a face FùêπFitalic_F, let ùí¢F={œÉ‚ààùí´n‚àí1‚à£wg(œÉ)=0\mathcal{G}_{F}=\{\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}\mid w_{g}(\sigma)=0caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_œÉ ‚àà caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à£ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œÉ ) = 0 for all (wg,wh)‚ààF}(w_{g},w_{h})\in F\}( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚àà italic_F } and ‚ÑãF={œÉ‚ààùí´fn‚àí1‚à£wh(œÉ)=0\mathcal{H}_{F}=\{\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-1}_{f}\mid w_{h}(\sigma)=0caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_œÉ ‚àà caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à£ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œÉ ) = 0 for all (wg,wh)‚ààF}(w_{g},w_{h})\in F\}( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚àà italic_F } be the set of facets where the corresponding inequalities ensuring convexity of the functions gùëîgitalic_g and h‚Ñéhitalic_h are tight. It is not hard to see that G‚äÜFùê∫ùêπG\subseteq Fitalic_G ‚äÜ italic_F if and only if ùí¢F‚äÜùí¢Gsubscriptùí¢ùêπsubscriptùí¢ùê∫\mathcal{G}_{F}\subseteq\mathcal{G}_{G}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚äÜ caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ‚ÑãF‚äÜ‚ÑãGsubscript‚Ñãùêπsubscript‚Ñãùê∫\mathcal{H}_{F}\subseteq\mathcal{H}_{G}caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚äÜ caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In other words, if (g‚Ä≤,h‚Ä≤)superscriptùëî‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is contained in a face G‚äÜFùê∫ùêπG\subseteq Fitalic_G ‚äÜ italic_F, then one can move from (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) to (g‚Ä≤,h‚Ä≤)superscriptùëî‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) without losing tight inequalities. Hence, Lemma 3.10 implies that (g‚Ä≤,h‚Ä≤)superscriptùëî‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is a coarsening of (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ). If G‚äÇFùê∫ùêπG\subset Fitalic_G ‚äÇ italic_F, then either ùí¢F‚äÇùí¢Gsubscriptùí¢ùêπsubscriptùí¢ùê∫\mathcal{G}_{F}\subset\mathcal{G}_{G}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚äÇ caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or ‚ÑãF‚äÇ‚ÑãGsubscript‚Ñãùêπsubscript‚Ñãùê∫\mathcal{H}_{F}\subset\mathcal{H}_{G}caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚äÇ caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Thus, another inequality becomes tight when moving from (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) to (g‚Ä≤,h‚Ä≤)superscriptùëî‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) implying that the coarsening is non-trivial.

For the converse direction, let (g‚Ä≤,h‚Ä≤)superscriptùëî‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) be a coarsening of (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ), which in particular means that g‚Ä≤superscriptùëî‚Ä≤g^{\prime}italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are compatible with ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P. Hence, f=g‚Ä≤‚àíh‚Ä≤ùëìsuperscriptùëî‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤f=g^{\prime}-h^{\prime}italic_f = italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT implies that (g‚Ä≤,h‚Ä≤)‚ààùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)superscriptùëî‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤subscriptùíüùí´ùëì(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚àà caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ). Now, assume that there is no face G‚äÜFùê∫ùêπG\subseteq Fitalic_G ‚äÜ italic_F such that (g‚Ä≤,h‚Ä≤)‚ààGsuperscriptùëî‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤ùê∫(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})\in G( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚àà italic_G. Then the line between (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) and (g‚Ä≤,h‚Ä≤)superscriptùëî‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is not contained in FùêπFitalic_F. Thus, a tight inequality gets lost when moving from (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) towards (g‚Ä≤,h‚Ä≤)superscriptùëî‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Hence, without loss of generality, there is a œÉ‚ààsuppùí´‚Å°(g‚Ä≤)‚àñsuppùí´‚Å°(g)ùúésubscriptsuppùí´superscriptùëî‚Ä≤subscriptsuppùí´ùëî\sigma\in\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}(g^{\prime})\setminus\operatorname{% supp}_{\mathcal{P}}(g)italic_œÉ ‚àà roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚àñ roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ), which according to Lemma 3.10 is a contradiction to (g‚Ä≤,h‚Ä≤)superscriptùëî‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) being a coarsening of (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ). ‚àé

Proof of Theorem 3.11.

1 and 2 are equivalent by Proposition E.5. 3 trivially implies 2. Hence, it remains to show 1 ‚üπ\implies‚üπ 3. Assume that there is a polyhedral complex ùí¨ùí¨\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q compatible with gùëîgitalic_g and h‚Ñéhitalic_h such that (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) is not a vertex of ùíüùí¨‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí¨ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{Q}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ). Then there is vertex (g‚Ä≤,h‚Ä≤)superscriptùëî‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) of ùíüùí¨‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí¨ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{Q}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) contained in the face containing (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ). By Proposition E.5, it follows that (g‚Ä≤,h‚Ä≤)superscriptùëî‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is a non-trivial coarsening of (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ). ‚àé

E.11 Proof of Theorem 3.13

Proof.

If (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) is not not a vertex, the by Theorem 3.11, there is a coarsening (g‚Ä≤,h‚Ä≤)superscriptùëî‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) of (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ). Thus, (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) is dominated by (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) and therefore not minimal. ‚àé

E.12 Proof of Proposition 3.14

Proof.

As ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí´ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) is nonempty, there must exist a minimal decomposition. By Theorem 3.13, every minimal decomposition must be a vertex. As there is only one vertex, it must coincide with the unique minimal decomposition. ‚àé

E.13 Lemma E.6

Lemma E.6.

Let C‚äÇ‚Ñùdùê∂superscript‚ÑùùëëC\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_C ‚äÇ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be a convex, pointed polyhedral cone. If Cùê∂Citalic_C is simplicial then C‚à©(C+t)ùê∂ùê∂ùë°C\cap(C+t)italic_C ‚à© ( italic_C + italic_t ) is a (potentially shifted) cone, i.e. a polyhedron with a single vertex, for any translation tùë°titalic_t. If Cùê∂Citalic_C is not simplicial, then C‚à©(C+t)ùê∂ùê∂ùë°C\cap(C+t)italic_C ‚à© ( italic_C + italic_t ) is a (shifted) cone if t‚ààCùë°ùê∂t\in Citalic_t ‚àà italic_C.

Proof.

If Cùê∂Citalic_C is a simplicial full-dimensional cone, then it is the image of the nonnegative orthant under an affine isomorphism. Thus, it suffices to show that C‚à©(C+t)ùê∂ùê∂ùë°C\cap(C+t)italic_C ‚à© ( italic_C + italic_t ) is a shifted cone for C=‚Ñù‚â•0dùê∂superscriptsubscript‚Ñùabsent0ùëëC=\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}^{d}italic_C = blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â• 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Let t^‚àà‚Ñùd^ùë°superscript‚Ñùùëë\hat{t}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}over^ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that t^i=max‚Å°(ti,0)subscript^ùë°ùëñsubscriptùë°ùëñ0\hat{t}_{i}=\max(t_{i},0)over^ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_max ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 0 ). Then

C‚à©(C+t)={x‚à£xi‚â•0‚Å¢ and ‚Å¢xi‚â•ti}={x‚à£xi‚â•t^i}=C+t^.ùê∂ùê∂ùë°conditional-setùë•subscriptùë•ùëñ0 and subscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùë°ùëñconditional-setùë•subscriptùë•ùëñsubscript^ùë°ùëñùê∂^ùë°C\cap(C+t)=\{x\mid x_{i}\geq 0\text{ and }x_{i}\geq t_{i}\}=\{x\mid x_{i}\geq% \hat{t}_{i}\}=C+\hat{t}.italic_C ‚à© ( italic_C + italic_t ) = { italic_x ‚à£ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â• 0 and italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â• italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } = { italic_x ‚à£ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â• over^ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } = italic_C + over^ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG .

On the other hand, if Cùê∂Citalic_C is an arbitrary polyhedral cone and t‚ààCùë°ùê∂t\in Citalic_t ‚àà italic_C, then C‚à©(C+t)=C+tùê∂ùê∂ùë°ùê∂ùë°C\cap(C+t)=C+titalic_C ‚à© ( italic_C + italic_t ) = italic_C + italic_t, and hence a shifted cone. ‚àé

Example E.7.

The converse of the second statement from Lemma E.6 does not hold, that is, t‚àâCùë°ùê∂t\not\in Citalic_t ‚àâ italic_C does not imply that C‚à©(C+t)ùê∂ùê∂ùë°C\cap(C+t)italic_C ‚à© ( italic_C + italic_t ) is not a shfited cone. Indeed, let C=cone‚Å°((100),(110),(101),(111))‚Å¢ and ‚Å¢t=(011).ùê∂cone100110101111 and ùë°011C=\operatorname{cone}\left(\left(\begin{smallmatrix}1\\ 0\\ 0\end{smallmatrix}\right),\left(\begin{smallmatrix}1\\ 1\\ 0\end{smallmatrix}\right),\left(\begin{smallmatrix}1\\ 0\\ 1\end{smallmatrix}\right),\left(\begin{smallmatrix}1\\ 1\\ 1\end{smallmatrix}\right)\right)\text{ and }t=\left(\begin{smallmatrix}0\\ 1\\ 1\end{smallmatrix}\right).italic_C = roman_cone ( ( start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW ) , ( start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW ) , ( start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW ) , ( start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW ) ) and italic_t = ( start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW ) . Then C‚à©(C+t)=C+(111)ùê∂ùê∂ùë°ùê∂111C\cap(C+t)=C+\left(\begin{smallmatrix}1\\ 1\\ 1\end{smallmatrix}\right)italic_C ‚à© ( italic_C + italic_t ) = italic_C + ( start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW ) is a shifted cone. On the other hand, the choice t=(012)ùë°012t=\left(\begin{smallmatrix}0\\ 1\\ 2\end{smallmatrix}\right)italic_t = ( start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 2 end_CELL end_ROW ) yields the unbounded polyhedron C‚à©(C+t)=conv‚Å°((222),(212))+C,ùê∂ùê∂ùë°conv222212ùê∂C\cap(C+t)=\operatorname{conv}\left(\left(\begin{smallmatrix}2\\ 2\\ 2\end{smallmatrix}\right),\left(\begin{smallmatrix}2\\ 1\\ 2\end{smallmatrix}\right)\right)+C,italic_C ‚à© ( italic_C + italic_t ) = roman_conv ( ( start_ROW start_CELL 2 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 2 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 2 end_CELL end_ROW ) , ( start_ROW start_CELL 2 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 2 end_CELL end_ROW ) ) + italic_C , which has two vertices and one line segment as bounded faces.

E.14 Proof of Proposition 3.15

Proof.

Let ùí¨ùí¨\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q be any regular complete complex that is compatible with fùëìfitalic_f. Then, gùëîgitalic_g and h‚Ñéhitalic_h are as well compatible with ùí¨ùí¨\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q, since suppùí´‚Å°(g),suppùí´‚Å°(h)‚äÜsuppùí´‚Å°(f)subscriptsuppùí´ùëîsubscriptsuppùí´‚Ñésubscriptsuppùí´ùëì\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}(g),\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}(h)% \subseteq\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{P}}(f)roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ) , roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_h ) ‚äÜ roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) implies that suppùí¨‚Å°(g),suppùí¨‚Å°(h)‚äÜsuppùí¨‚Å°(f)subscriptsuppùí¨ùëîsubscriptsuppùí¨‚Ñésubscriptsuppùí¨ùëì\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{Q}}(g),\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{Q}}(h)% \subseteq\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{Q}}(f)roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ) , roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_h ) ‚äÜ roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ). Let (g‚Ä≤,h‚Ä≤)‚ààùíüùí¨‚Å¢(f)superscriptùëî‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤subscriptùíüùí¨ùëì(g^{\prime},h^{\prime})\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{Q}}(f)( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚àà caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ). Then it holds that suppùí¨+‚Å°(f)‚äÜsuppùí¨‚Å°(g‚Ä≤)subscriptsuperscriptsuppùí¨ùëìsubscriptsuppùí¨superscriptùëî‚Ä≤\operatorname{supp}^{+}_{\mathcal{Q}}(f)\subseteq\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal% {Q}}(g^{\prime})roman_supp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ‚äÜ roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) since wg‚àíwf=wh‚â•0subscriptùë§ùëîsubscriptùë§ùëìsubscriptùë§‚Ñé0w_{g}-w_{f}=w_{h}\geq 0italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â• 0. Hence, suppùí¨‚Å°(g)‚äÜsuppùí¨‚Å°(g‚Ä≤)subscriptsuppùí¨ùëîsubscriptsuppùí¨superscriptùëî‚Ä≤\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{Q}}(g)\subseteq\operatorname{supp}_{\mathcal{Q}}% (g^{\prime})roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ) ‚äÜ roman_supp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and Lemma 3.10 implies that gùëîgitalic_g is a coarsening of g‚Ä≤superscriptùëî‚Ä≤g^{\prime}italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and analogously it follows that h‚Ñéhitalic_h is a coarsening of h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore, (g,h)ùëî‚Ñé(g,h)( italic_g , italic_h ) is a coarsening of every decomposition and thus by Theorem 3.11 the only vertex of ùíüùí¨‚Å¢(f)subscriptùíüùí¨ùëì\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{Q}}(f)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ). Clearly, gùëîgitalic_g and h‚Ñéhitalic_h cannot have more pieces than fùëìfitalic_f. ‚àé

E.15 Proof of Theorem 3.18

Before proving this statement, we give a description of the dual cone (ùí±¬Øùí´+)‚à®superscriptsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´(\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+})^{\vee}( over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à® end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Recall that ùí±¬Øùí´+‚âÖ‚ãÇœÉ‚ààùí´n‚àí1{w‚ààùí≤ùí´‚à£w‚Å¢(œÉ)‚â•0}superscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´subscriptùúésuperscriptùí´ùëõ1conditional-setùë§subscriptùí≤ùí´ùë§ùúé0\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}\cong\bigcap_{\sigma\in\mathcal{P}^{n-% 1}}\{w\in\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}\mid w(\sigma)\geq 0\}over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚âÖ ‚ãÇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÉ ‚àà caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_w ‚àà caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à£ italic_w ( italic_œÉ ) ‚â• 0 }, i.e., the intersection of the nonnegative orthant {w‚Å¢(œÉ)‚â•0}ùë§ùúé0\{w(\sigma)\geq 0\}{ italic_w ( italic_œÉ ) ‚â• 0 } with the linear space ùí≤ùí´subscriptùí≤ùí´\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. By duality of intersections and sums, it follows that (ùí±¬Øùí´+)‚à®superscriptsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´(\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+})^{\vee}( over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à® end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is isomorphic to the Minkowksi sum of the nonnegative orthant with ùí≤ùí´‚üÇsuperscriptsubscriptùí≤ùí´perpendicular-to\mathcal{W}_{\mathcal{P}}^{\perp}caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In particular, any wùë§witalic_w with positive weights w‚Å¢(œÉ)>0ùë§ùúé0w(\sigma)>0italic_w ( italic_œÉ ) > 0 lies in the interior. Theorem 3.18 follows from a general fact about face of polyhedra.

Lemma E.8.

Let Cùê∂Citalic_C be a convex, pointed polyhedral cone and PùëÉPitalic_P a polyhedron with recession cone Cùê∂Citalic_C. Then u‚ààint‚Å°(C‚à®)ùë¢intsuperscriptùê∂u\in\operatorname{int}(C^{\vee})italic_u ‚àà roman_int ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à® end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is a direction in the interior of the dual cone of Cùê∂Citalic_C if and only if the face PusuperscriptùëÉùë¢P^{u}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of PùëÉPitalic_P which is minimized by uùë¢uitalic_u is a bounded face.

Proof.

Let P=C+QùëÉùê∂ùëÑP=C+Qitalic_P = italic_C + italic_Q, where QùëÑQitalic_Q is a bounded polyhedron. Then for any direction uùë¢uitalic_u holds Pu=Cu+QusuperscriptùëÉùë¢superscriptùê∂ùë¢superscriptùëÑùë¢P^{u}=C^{u}+Q^{u}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. As Cùê∂Citalic_C is a pointed cone, we have that Cusuperscriptùê∂ùë¢C^{u}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is bounded if and only if u‚ààint‚Å°(C‚à®)ùë¢intsuperscriptùê∂u\in\operatorname{int}(C^{\vee})italic_u ‚àà roman_int ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à® end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Since QusuperscriptùëÑùë¢Q^{u}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is bounded for any direction, it follows that PusuperscriptùëÉùë¢P^{u}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is bounded if and only if u‚ààint‚Å°(C‚à®)ùë¢intsuperscriptùê∂u\in\operatorname{int}(C^{\vee})italic_u ‚àà roman_int ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à® end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). ‚àé

Proof of Theorem 3.18.

P=ùí±¬Øùí´+‚à©(ùí±¬Øùí´++f)ùëÉsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´superscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´ùëìP=\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}\cap(\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{% \mathcal{P}}^{+}+f)italic_P = over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à© ( over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_f ) is a polyhedron with recession cone ùí±¬Øùí´+superscriptsubscript¬Øùí±ùí´\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+}over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Applying Lemma E.8 yields that for any u‚àà(int((ùí±¬Øùí´+)‚à®)u\in(\operatorname{int}((\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{\mathcal{P}}^{+})^{\vee})italic_u ‚àà ( roman_int ( ( over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à® end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), every minimizer in œÄ‚Å¢(ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f))ùúãsubscriptùíüùí´ùëì\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))italic_œÄ ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ) lies in a bounded face, which, by Theorem 3.8, are precisely the reduced decompositions. Moreover, if œÄ‚Å¢(ùíüùí´‚Å¢(f))ùúãsubscriptùíüùí´ùëì\pi(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{P}}(f))italic_œÄ ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) ) contains a unique vertex then by Proposition 3.14 this coincides with the unique minimal decompoition. ‚àé

E.16 Proof of Theorem 6.1

Proof.

In the convex case, this is literally proven by Hertrich et al. (2021). While Hertrich et al. (2021) have a slightly weaker bound for the nonconvex case, it follows from Koutschan et al. (2023, Thm. 2.4) that the stronger bound for the convex case also applies to the nonconvex case. ‚àé

E.17 Proof of Theorem 6.3

Proof.

Recall that a convex CPWL function can be written as the maximum of its affine components, that is, f‚Å¢(x)=maxi‚àà[k]‚Å°aiT‚Å¢x+biùëìùë•subscriptùëñdelimited-[]ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëéùëñùëáùë•subscriptùëèùëñf(x)=\max_{i\in[k]}a_{i}^{T}x+b_{i}italic_f ( italic_x ) = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ italic_k ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The idea is to split the kùëòkitalic_k affine components of fùëìfitalic_f into rùëüritalic_r groups of size at most sùë†sitalic_s, apply Theorem 6.1 to compute the maximum within each group, and then simply compute the maximum of the rùëüritalic_r group maxima in a straight-forward way.

Let us first focus on computing the maximum of at most sùë†sitalic_s affine components within each of the rùëüritalic_r groups. By Theorem 6.1, one can achieve this with a neural network of depth ‚åàlog2‚Å°(n+1)‚åâ+1subscript2ùëõ11\lceil\log_{2}(n+1)\rceil+1‚åà roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_n + 1 ) ‚åâ + 1 and overall size ùí™‚Å¢(sn+1)ùí™superscriptùë†ùëõ1\mathcal{O}(s^{n+1})caligraphic_O ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). We put all these rùëüritalic_r neural networks in parallel to each other and add, at the end, the simple neural network computing the maximum of these rùëüritalic_r maxima according to Arora et al. (2018), which has depth ‚åàlog2‚Å°r‚åâ+1subscript2ùëü1\lceil\log_{2}r\rceil+1‚åà roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r ‚åâ + 1 and overall size ùí™‚Å¢(r)ùí™ùëü\mathcal{O}(r)caligraphic_O ( italic_r ). Altogether, the resulting neural network will have the desired depth and size. ‚àé

E.18 Proof of Corollary 6.4

Proof.

By Lemma E.3, fùëìfitalic_f can be decomposed into a difference of two convex functions which are compatible with ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P. Consequently, each of them has at most q~~ùëû\tilde{q}over~ start_ARG italic_q end_ARG affine components. Applying Theorem 6.3 to both functions separately and simply putting the two corresponding neural networks in parallel, subtracting the outputs, yields a neural network representing fùëìfitalic_f with the desired size bounds. ‚àé

Report Github Issue

Instructions for reporting errors

We are continuing to improve HTML versions of papers, and your feedback helps enhance accessibility and mobile support. To report errors in the HTML that will help us improve conversion and rendering, choose any of the methods listed below:

  • Click the "Report Issue" button.
  • Open a report feedback form via keyboard, use "Ctrl + ?".
  • Make a text selection and click the "Report Issue for Selection" button near your cursor.
  • You can use Alt+Y to toggle on and Alt+Shift+Y to toggle off accessible reporting links at each section.

Our team has already identified the following issues. We appreciate your time reviewing and reporting rendering errors we may not have found yet. Your efforts will help us improve the HTML versions for all readers, because disability should not be a barrier to accessing research. Thank you for your continued support in championing open access for all.

Have a free development cycle? Help support accessibility at arXiv! Our collaborators at LaTeXML maintain a list of packages that need conversion, and welcome developer contributions.
